abbreviate.snippet: abbreviate(${1:names.arg}, ${2:minlength = 4, use.classes = TRUE, dot = FALSE, strict = FALSE, method = c("left.kept", "both.sides"})
abbreviate.displayText: abbreviate(names.arg, minlength = 4, use.classes = TRUE, dot = FALSE, strict = FALSE, method = c("left.kept", "both.sides")
abbreviate.description: Abbreviate strings to at least minlength characters, such that they remain unique (if they were), unless strict = TRUE.

sqrt.description: abs(x) computes the absolute value of x, sqrt(x) computes the (principal) square root of x, √{x}.

tanpi.description: These functions give the obvious trigonometric functions. They respectively compute the cosine, sine, tangent, arc-cosine, arc-sine, arc-tangent, and the two-argument arc-tangent.

atanh.description: These functions give the obvious hyperbolic functions. They respectively compute the hyperbolic cosine, sine, tangent, and their inverses, arc-cosine, arc-sine, arc-tangent (or ‘area cosine’, etc).

snippet: factor(${1:x = character(${1:)}, ${2:levels, labels = levels, exclude = NA, ordered = is.ordered(x), nmax = NA)})
displayText: factor(x = character(), levels, labels = levels, exclude = NA, ordered = is.ordered(x), nmax = NA)
addNA.description: The function factor is used to encode a vector as a factor (the terms ‘category’ and ‘enumerated type’ are also used for factors). If argument ordered is TRUE, the factor levels are assumed to be ordered. For compatibility with S there is also a function ordered.

removeTaskCallback.description: addTaskCallback registers an R function that is to be called each time a top-level task is completed.
removeTaskCallback.rightLabel: Add or Remove a Top-Level Task Callback

snippet: agrep(${1:pattern}, ${2:x, max.distance = 0.1, costs = NULL,ignore.case = FALSE, value = FALSE, fixed = TRUE,useBytes = FALSE})
agrepl(${1:pattern}, ${2:x, max.distance = 0.1, costs = NULL, ignore.case = FALSE, fixed = TRUE, useBytes = FALSE})
displayText: agrep(pattern, x, max.distance = 0.1, costs = NULL,ignore.case = FALSE, value = FALSE, fixed = TRUE,useBytes = FALSE)
agrepl(pattern, x, max.distance = 0.1, costs = NULL, ignore.case = FALSE, fixed = TRUE, useBytes = FALSE)
agrepl.description: Searches for approximate matches to pattern (the first argument) within each element of the string x (the second argument) using the generalized Levenshtein edit distance (the minimal possibly weighted number of insertions, deletions and substitutions needed to transform one string into another).

alist.description: Functions to construct, coerce and check for both kinds of R lists.

all.description: Given a set of logical vectors, are all of the values true?

snippet: all.equal(${1:target}, ${2:current,tolerance = sqrt(.Machine$double.eps), scale = NULL,..., check.attributes = TRUE)})
displayText: all.equal(target, current,tolerance = sqrt(.Machine$double.eps), scale = NULL,..., check.attributes = TRUE)
attr.all.equal(target, current, ..., check.attributes = TRUE, check.names = TRUE)
attr.all.equal.description: all.equal(x, y) is a utility to compare R objects x and y testing ‘near equality’. If they are different, comparison is still made to some extent, and a report of the differences is returned.  Do not use all.equal directly in if expressions—either use isTRUE(all.equal(....)) or identical if appropriate.
attr.all.equal.rightLabel: Test if Two Objects are (Nearly) Equal

displayText: all.names(expr, functions = TRUE, max.names = -1L, unique = FALSE)
all.vars(expr, functions = FALSE, max.names = -1L, unique = TRUE)
all.vars.description: Return a character vector containing all the names which occur in an expression or call.
all.vars.rightLabel: Find All Names in an Expression

any.description: Given a set of logical vectors, is at least one of the values true?

snippet: duplicated(${1:x}, ${2:incomparables = FALSE, fromLast = FALSE, nmax = NA, ...})
displayText: duplicated(x, incomparables = FALSE, fromLast = FALSE, nmax = NA, ...)
duplicated(x, incomparables = FALSE, MARGIN = 1, fromLast = FALSE, ...)
anyDuplicated(x, incomparables = FALSE, MARGIN = 1, fromLast = FALSE, ...)
anyDuplicated.description: duplicated() determines which elements of a vector or data frame are duplicates of elements with smaller subscripts, and returns a logical vector indicating which elements (rows) are duplicates.

is.na.description: NA is a logical constant of length 1 which contains a missing value indicator. NA can be coerced to any other vector type except raw. There are also constants NA_integer_, NA_real_, NA_complex_ and NA_character_ of the other atomic vector types which support missing values: all of these are reserved words in the R language.

getRversion.description: A simple S3 class for representing numeric versions including package versions, and associated methods.

summary.description: Description of the classes "POSIXlt" and "POSIXct" representing calendar dates and times.

displayText: aperm(a, perm = NULL, resize = TRUE, keep.class = TRUE, ...)
aperm.description: Transpose an array by permuting its dimensions and optionally resizing it.

apply.description: Returns a vector or array or list of values obtained by applying a function to margins of an array or matrix.

displayText: complex(length.out = 0, real = numeric(), imaginary = numeric(),modulus = 1, argument = 0)
Conj.description: Basic functions which support complex arithmetic in R.

args.description: Displays the argument names and corresponding default values of a function or primitive.

displayText: array(data = NA, dim = length(data), dimnames = NULL)

arrayInd.description: Give the TRUE indices of a logical object, allowing for array indices.

as.call.description: Create or test for objects of mode "call".

is.character.description: Create or test for objects of type "character".

.handleSimpleError.description: These functions provide a mechanism for handling unusual conditions, including errors and warnings.

as.character.description: Functions to convert between character representations and objects of class "Date" representing calendar dates.
as.character.rightLabel: Date Conversion Functions to and from Character

print.description: Convert or print integers in hexadecimal format, with as many digits as are needed to display the largest, using leading zeroes as necessary.

print.1.description: Convert or print integers in octal format, with as many digits as are needed to display the largest, using leading zeroes as necessary.

strptime.description: Functions to convert between character representations and objects of classes "POSIXlt" and "POSIXct" representing calendar dates and times.
strptime.rightLabel: Date-time Conversion Functions to and from Character

.isOpen.description: These functions are for working with source files.

is.data.frame.description: Functions to check if an object is a data frame, or coerce it if possible.

summary.1.description: Description of the class "Date" representing calendar dates.

snippet: table(${1:...}, ${2:exclude = if (useNA == "no") c(NA, NaN), useNA = c("no","ifany", "always"), dnn = list.names(...), deparse.level = 1})
as.data.frame(${1:x}, ${2:row.names = NULL, ...,responseName = "Freq", stringsAsFactors = TRUE,sep = "", base = list(LETTERS})
displayText: table(..., exclude = if (useNA == "no") c(NA, NaN), useNA = c("no","ifany", "always"), dnn = list.names(...), deparse.level = 1)
as.data.frame(x, row.names = NULL, ...,responseName = "Freq", stringsAsFactors = TRUE,sep = "", base = list(LETTERS)
as.data.frame.description: table uses the cross-classifying factors to build a contingency table of the counts at each combination of factor levels.

Math.description: Time intervals creation, printing, and some arithmetic. The print() method calls these “time differences”.

as.single.description: Create, coerce to or test for a double-precision vector.

as.double.description: Functions to manipulate objects of classes "POSIXlt" and "POSIXct" representing calendar dates and times.

as.environment.description: A generic function coercing an R object to an environment. A number or a character string is converted to the corresponding environment on the search path.

as.expression.description: Creates or tests for objects of mode "expression".

as.function.description: as.function is a generic function which is used to convert objects to functions.

is.integer.description: Creates or tests for objects of type "integer".

is.logical.description: Create or test for objects of type "logical", and the basic logical constants.

snippet: matrix(${1:data = NA}, ${2:nrow = 1, ncol = 1, byrow = FALSE, dimnames = NULL})
displayText: matrix(data = NA, nrow = 1, ncol = 1, byrow = FALSE, dimnames = NULL)
is.matrix.description: matrix creates a matrix from the given set of values.

c.rightLabel: Class for ‘no quote’ Printing of Character Strings

is.name.description: A ‘name’ (also known as a ‘symbol’) is a way to refer to R objects by name (rather than the value of the object, if any, bound to that name).

is.null.description: NULL represents the null object in R: it is a reserved word. NULL is often returned by expressions and functions whose value is undefined.

is.numeric.description: Creates or coerces objects of type "numeric". is.numeric is a more general test of an object being interpretable as numbers.

as.qr.description: qr computes the QR decomposition of a matrix.
as.qr.rightLabel: The QR Decomposition of a Matrix

is.raw.description: Creates or tests for objects of type "raw".

is.vector.description: vector produces a vector of the given length and mode.

I.description: Change the class of an object to indicate that it should be treated ‘as is’.

asS3.description: Tests whether the object is an instance of an S4 class.

assign.snippet: assign(${1:x}, ${2:value, pos = -1, envir = as.environment(pos), inherits = FALSE, immediate = TRUE)})
assign.displayText: assign(x, value, pos = -1, envir = as.environment(pos), inherits = FALSE, immediate = TRUE)
assign.description: Assign a value to a name in an environment.
assign.rightLabel: Assign a Value to a Name

attach.displayText: attach(what, pos = 2L, name = deparse(substitute(what)), warn.conflicts = TRUE)
attach.description: The database is attached to the R search path. This means that the database is searched by R when evaluating a variable, so objects in the database can be accessed by simply giving their names.
attach.rightLabel: Attach Set of R Objects to Search Path

snippet: loadNamespace(${1:package}, ${2:lib.loc = NULL,keep.source = getOption("keep.source.pkgs"),partial = FALSE, versionCheck = NULL)})
displayText: loadNamespace(package, lib.loc = NULL,keep.source = getOption("keep.source.pkgs"),partial = FALSE, versionCheck = NULL)
isNamespaceLoaded.description: Functions to load and unload name spaces.

attr.description: Get or set specific attributes of an object.

attributes.description: These functions access an object's attributes. The first form below returns the object's attribute list. The replacement forms uses the list on the right-hand side of the assignment as the object's attributes (if appropriate).

autoloader.description: autoload creates a promise-to-evaluate autoloader and stores it with name name in .AutoloadEnv environment. When R attempts to evaluate name, autoloader is run, the package is loaded and name is re-evaluated in the new package's environment. The result is that R behaves as if file was loaded but it does not occupy memory.

snippet: backsolve(${1:r}, ${2:x, k = ncol(r), upper.tri = TRUE, transpose = FALSE)})
forwardsolve(${1:l}, ${2:x, k = ncol(l), upper.tri = FALSE, transpose = FALSE)})
displayText: backsolve(r, x, k = ncol(r), upper.tri = TRUE, transpose = FALSE)
forwardsolve(l, x, k = ncol(l), upper.tri = FALSE, transpose = FALSE)
forwardsolve.description: Solves a triangular system of linear equations.
forwardsolve.rightLabel: Solve an Upper or Lower Triangular System

env.profile.description: Get, set, test for and create environments.

dirname.description: basename removes all of the path up to and including the last path separator (if any).

besselY.description: Bessel Functions of integer and fractional order, of first and second kind, J(nu) and Y(nu), and Modified Bessel functions (of first and third kind), I(nu) and K(nu).

lfactorial.description: Special mathematical functions related to the beta and gamma functions.

bindingIsActive.description: These functions represent an interface for adjustments to environments and bindings within environments. They allow for locking environments as well as individual bindings, and for linking a variable to a function.
bindingIsActive.rightLabel: Binding and Environment Locking, Active Bindings

bindtextdomain.description: If Native Language Support was enabled in this build of R, attempt to translate character vectors or set where the translations are to be found.

bitwShiftR.description: Logical operations on integer vectors with elements viewed as sets of bits.

body.description: Get or set the body of a function.
body.rightLabel: Access to and Manipulation of the Body of a Function

bquote.description: An analogue of the LISP backquote macro. bquote quotes its argument except that terms wrapped in .() are evaluated in the specified where environment.

snippet: for(${1:var in seq) exprwhile(${1:cond) exprrepeat exprbreaknext})
displayText: for(var in seq) exprwhile(cond) exprrepeat exprbreaknext)
for.description: These are the basic control-flow constructs of the R language. They function in much the same way as control statements in any Algol-like language. They are all reserved words.

browser.displayText: browser(text = "", condition = NULL, expr = TRUE, skipCalls = 0L)
browser.description: Interrupt the execution of an expression and allow the inspection of the environment where browser was called from.

browserSetDebug.description: A call to browser can provide context by supplying either a text argument or a condition argument. These functions can be used to retrieve either of these arguments.
browserSetDebug.rightLabel: Functions to Retrieve Values Supplied by Calls to the Browser

builtins.description: Return the names of all the built-in objects. These are fetched directly from the symbol table of the R interpreter.
builtins.rightLabel: Returns the Names of All Built-in Objects

by.description: Function by is an object-oriented wrapper for tapply applied to data frames.
by.rightLabel: Apply a Function to a Data Frame Split by Factors

snippet: file(${1:description = ""}, ${2:open = "", blocking = TRUE, encoding = getOption("encoding"), raw = FALSE)})
socketConnection(${1:host = "localhost"}, ${2:port, server = FALSE, blocking = FALSE, open = "a+", encoding = getOption("encoding"), timeout = getOption("timeout")})
displayText: file(description = "", open = "", blocking = TRUE, encoding = getOption("encoding"), raw = FALSE)
url(description, open = "", blocking = TRUE,encoding = getOption("encoding"), method)
fifo(description, open = "", blocking = FALSE, encoding = getOption("encoding"))
socketConnection(host = "localhost", port, server = FALSE, blocking = FALSE, open = "a+", encoding = getOption("encoding"), timeout = getOption("timeout"))
isIncomplete.description: Functions to create, open and close connections, i.e., “generalized files”, such as possibly compressed files, URLs, pipes, etc.

c.1.description: This is a generic function which combines its arguments.
c.1.rightLabel: Combine Values into a Vector or List

warnings.description: warnings and its print method print the variable last.warning in a pleasing form.

callCC.description: A downward-only version of Scheme's call with current continuation.

capabilities.description: Report on the optional features which have been compiled into this build of R.
capabilities.rightLabel: Report Capabilities of this Build of R

casefold.description: Translate characters in character vectors, in particular from upper to lower case or vice versa.

cat.snippet: cat(${1:... }, ${2:file = "", sep = " ", fill = FALSE, labels = NULL,append = FALSE})
cat.displayText: cat(... , file = "", sep = " ", fill = FALSE, labels = NULL,append = FALSE)
cat.description: Outputs the objects, concatenating the representations. cat performs much less conversion than print.

rbind.description: Take a sequence of vector, matrix or data-frame arguments and combine by columns or rows, respectively. These are generic functions with methods for other R classes.
rbind.rightLabel: Combine R Objects by Rows or Columns

signif.description: ceiling takes a single numeric argument x and returns a numeric vector containing the smallest integers not less than the corresponding elements of x.

char.expand.description: Seeks a unique match of its first argument among the elements of its second. If successful, it returns this element; otherwise, it performs an action specified by the third argument.
char.expand.rightLabel: Expand a String with Respect to a Target Table

charmatch.description: charmatch seeks matches for the elements of its first argument among those of its second.

packBits.description: Conversion and manipulation of objects of type "raw".
packBits.rightLabel: Convert to or from Raw Vectors

chkDots.description: Warn about extraneous arguments in the ... of its caller. A utility to be used e.g., in S3 methods which need a formal ... argument but do not make any use of it. This helps catching user errors in calling the function in question (which is the caller of chkDots().
chkDots.rightLabel: Warn About Extraneous Arguments in the "..." of Its Caller

chol.description: Compute the Choleski factorization of a real symmetric positive-definite square matrix.

chol2inv.description: Invert a symmetric, positive definite square matrix from its Choleski decomposition. Equivalently, compute (X'X)^(-1) from the (R part) of the QR decomposition of X.

oldClass.description: R possesses a simple generic function mechanism which can be used for an object-oriented style of programming. Method dispatch takes place based on the class of the first argument to the generic function.

displayText: pushBack(data, connection, newLine = TRUE, encoding = c("", "bytes", "UTF-8")
clearPushBack.description: Functions to push back text lines onto a connection, and to enquire how many lines are currently pushed back.
clearPushBack.rightLabel: Push Text Back on to a Connection

function.description: These functions provide the base mechanisms for defining new functions in the R language.

intToUtf8.description: Conversion of UTF-8 encoded character vectors to and from integer vectors.
intToUtf8.rightLabel: Convert Integer Vectors to or from UTF-8-encoded Character Vectors

col.description: Returns a matrix of integers indicating their column number in a matrix-like object, or a factor of column labels.

.rowMeans.description: Form row and column sums and means for numeric arrays.
.rowMeans.rightLabel: Form Row and Column Sums and Means

colnames.description: Retrieve or set the row or column names of a matrix-like object.

commandArgs.description: Provides access to a copy of the command line arguments supplied when this R session was invoked.

comment.description: These functions set and query a comment attribute for any R objects. This is typically useful for data.frames or model fits.

Summary.description: Group generic methods can be defined for four pre-specified groups of functions, Math, Ops, Summary and Complex. (There are no objects of these names in base R, but there are in the methods package.)

conflicts.description: conflicts reports on objects that exist with the same name in two or more places on the search path, usually because an object in the user's workspace or a package is masking a system object of the same name. This helps discover unintentional masking.
conflicts.rightLabel: Search for Masked Objects on the Search Path

contributors.description: The R Who-is-who, describing who made significant contributions to the development of R.

tcrossprod.description: Given matrices x and y as arguments, return a matrix cross-product. This is formally equivalent to (but usually slightly faster than) the call t(x) %*% y (crossprod) or x %*% t(y) (tcrossprod).

Cstack_info.description: Report information on the C stack size and usage (if available).
Cstack_info.rightLabel: Report Information on C Stack Size and Usage

cummin.description: Returns a vector whose elements are the cumulative sums, products, minima or maxima of the elements of the argument.

curlGetHeaders.description: Retrieve the headers for a URL for a supported protocol such as http://, ftp://, https:// and ftps://. An optional function not supported on all platforms.

snippet: cut(${1:x}, ${2:breaks, labels = NULL,include.lowest = FALSE, right = TRUE, dig.lab = 3,ordered_result = FALSE, ...})
displayText: cut(x, breaks, labels = NULL,include.lowest = FALSE, right = TRUE, dig.lab = 3,ordered_result = FALSE, ...)
cut.description: cut divides the range of x into intervals and codes the values in x according to which interval they fall. The leftmost interval corresponds to level one, the next leftmost to level two and so on.

snippet: cut(${1:x}, ${2:breaks, labels = NULL, start.on.monday = TRUE,right = FALSE, ...})
cut(${1:x}, ${2:breaks, labels = NULL, start.on.monday = TRUE,right = FALSE, ...})
displayText: cut(x, breaks, labels = NULL, start.on.monday = TRUE,right = FALSE, ...)
cut(x, breaks, labels = NULL, start.on.monday = TRUE,right = FALSE, ...)
cut.1.description: Method for cut applied to date-time objects.
cut.1.rightLabel: Convert a Date or Date-Time Object to a Factor

data.class.description: Determine the class of an arbitrary R object.

snippet: data.frame(${1:...}, ${2:row.names = NULL, check.rows = FALSE, check.names = TRUE, stringsAsFactors = default.stringsAsFactors())})
displayText: data.frame(..., row.names = NULL, check.rows = FALSE, check.names = TRUE, stringsAsFactors = default.stringsAsFactors())
default.stringsAsFactors.description: This function creates data frames, tightly coupled collections of variables which share many of the properties of matrices and of lists, used as the fundamental data structure by most of R's modeling software.

data.matrix.description: Return the matrix obtained by converting all the variables in a data frame to numeric mode and then binding them together as the columns of a matrix. Factors and ordered factors are replaced by their internal codes.
data.matrix.rightLabel: Convert a Data Frame to a Numeric Matrix

date.description: Returns a character string of the current system date and time.

debuggingState.description: Set, unset or query the debugging flag on a function. The text and condition arguments are the same as those that can be supplied via a call to browser. They can be retrieved by the user once the browser has been entered, and provide a mechanism to allow users to identify which breakpoint has been activated.

.Defunct.description: When a function is removed from R it should be replaced by a function which calls .Defunct.

delayedAssign.description: delayedAssign creates a promise to evaluate the given expression if its value is requested. This provides direct access to the lazy evaluation mechanism used by R for the evaluation of (interpreted) functions.

deparse.description: Turn unevaluated expressions into character strings.

.Deprecated.description: When an object is about to be removed from R it is first deprecated and should include a call to .Deprecated.

determinant.description: det calculates the determinant of a matrix. determinant is a generic function that returns separately the modulus of the determinant, optionally on the logarithm scale, and the sign of the determinant.
determinant.rightLabel: Calculate the Determinant of a Matrix

detach.snippet: detach(${1:name}, ${2:pos = 2L, unload = FALSE, character.only = FALSE, force = FALSE})
detach.displayText: detach(name, pos = 2L, unload = FALSE, character.only = FALSE, force = FALSE)
detach.description: Detach a database, i.e., remove it from the search() path of available R objects. Usually this is either a data.frame which has been attached or a package which was attached by library.
detach.rightLabel: Detach Objects from the Search Path

dget.description: Writes an ASCII text representation of an R object to a file or connection, or uses one to recreate the object.
dget.rightLabel: Write an Object to a File or Recreate it

diag.description: Extract or replace the diagonal of a matrix, or construct a diagonal matrix.

diff.description: Returns suitably lagged and iterated differences.

dim.description: Retrieve or set the dimension of an object.

displayText: provideDimnames(x, sep = "", base = list(LETTERS), unique = TRUE)
provideDimnames.description: Retrieve or set the dimnames of an object.

snippet: list.files(${1:path = "."}, ${2:pattern = NULL, all.files = FALSE, full.names = FALSE, recursive = FALSE, ignore.case = FALSE, include.dirs = FALSE, no.. = FALSE})
dir(${1:path = "."}, ${2:pattern = NULL, all.files = FALSE, full.names = FALSE, recursive = FALSE, ignore.case = FALSE, include.dirs = FALSE, no.. = FALSE})
displayText: list.files(path = ".", pattern = NULL, all.files = FALSE, full.names = FALSE, recursive = FALSE, ignore.case = FALSE, include.dirs = FALSE, no.. = FALSE)
dir(path = ".", pattern = NULL, all.files = FALSE, full.names = FALSE, recursive = FALSE, ignore.case = FALSE, include.dirs = FALSE, no.. = FALSE)
list.dirs.description: These functions produce a character vector of the names of files or directories in the named directory.
list.dirs.rightLabel: List the Files in a Directory/Folder

displayText: dir.create(path, showWarnings = TRUE, recursive = FALSE, mode = "0777")
Sys.umask.description: These functions provide a low-level interface to the computer's file system.
Sys.umask.rightLabel: Manipulaton of Directories and File Permissions

getLoadedDLLs.description: This function provides a way to get a list of all the DLLs (see dyn.load) that are currently loaded in the R session.
getLoadedDLLs.rightLabel: Get DLLs Loaded in Current Session

do.call.displayText: do.call(what, args, quote = FALSE, envir = parent.frame()
do.call.description: do.call constructs and executes a function call from a name or a function and a list of arguments to be passed to it.

dontCheck.description: The dontCheck function is the same as identity, but is interpreted by R CMD check code analysis as a directive to suppress checking of x. Currently this is only used by checkFF(registration = TRUE) when checking the .NAME argument of foreign function calls.

dQuote.description: Single or double quote text by combining with appropriate single or double left and right quotation marks.

drop.description: Delete the dimensions of an array which have only one level.

droplevels.description: The function droplevels is used to drop unused levels from a factor or, more commonly, from factors in a data frame.

dump.snippet: dump(${1:list}, ${2:file = "dumpdata.R", append = FALSE, control = "all", envir = parent.frame(), evaluate = TRUE)})
dump.displayText: dump(list, file = "dumpdata.R", append = FALSE, control = "all", envir = parent.frame(), evaluate = TRUE)
dump.description: This function takes a vector of names of R objects and produces text representations of the objects on a file or connection. A dump file can usually be sourced into another R session.

is.loaded.description: Load or unload DLLs (also known as shared objects), and test whether a C function or Fortran subroutine is available.

snippet: mget(${1:x}, ${2:envir = as.environment(-1), mode = "any", ifnotfound, inherits = FALSE)})
displayText: get(x, pos = -1, envir = as.environment(pos), mode = "any",inherits = TRUE)
mget(x, envir = as.environment(-1), mode = "any", ifnotfound, inherits = FALSE)
dynGet.description: Search by name for an object (get) or zero or more objects (mget).
dynGet.rightLabel: Return the Value of a Named Object

eapply.displayText: eapply(env, FUN, ..., all.names = FALSE, USE.NAMES = TRUE)
eapply.description: eapply applies FUN to the named values from an environment and returns the results as a list. The user can request that all named objects are used (normally names that begin with a dot are not). The output is not sorted and no enclosing environments are searched.
eapply.rightLabel: Apply a Function Over Values in an Environment

eigen.displayText: eigen(x, symmetric, only.values = FALSE, EISPACK = FALSE)
eigen.description: Computes eigenvalues and eigenvectors of numeric (double, integer, logical) or complex matrices.

enc2utf8.description: Read or set the declared encodings for a character vector.
enc2utf8.rightLabel: Read or Set the Declared Encodings for a Character Vector

encodeString.snippet: encodeString(${1:x}, ${2:width = 0, quote = "", na.encode = TRUE, justify = c("left", "right", "centre", "none"})
encodeString.displayText: encodeString(x, width = 0, quote = "", na.encode = TRUE, justify = c("left", "right", "centre", "none")
encodeString.description: encodeString escapes the strings in a character vector in the same way print.default does, and optionally fits the encoded strings within a field width.
encodeString.rightLabel: Encode Character Vector as for Printing

substring.description: Determines if entries of x start or end with string (entries of) prefix or suffix respectively, where strings are recycled to common lengths.
substring.rightLabel: Does String Start or End With Another String?

enquote.description: substitute returns the parse tree for the (unevaluated) expression expr, substituting any variables bound in env.

displayText: eval(expr, envir = parent.frame(), enclos = if(is.list(envir) || is.pairlist(envir)
local.description: Evaluate an R expression in a specified environment.

snippet: exists(${1:x}, ${2:where = -1, envir = , frame, mode = "any", inherits = TRUE})

get0(x, envir = pos.to.env(-1L), mode = "any", inherits = TRUE, ifnotfound = NULL)
get0.description: Look for an R object of the given name and possibly return it

expm1.description: log computes logarithms, by default natural logarithms, log10 computes common (i.e., base 10) logarithms, and log2 computes binary (i.e., base 2) logarithms. The general form log(x, base) computes logarithms with base base.

expand.grid.description: Create a data frame from all combinations of the supplied vectors or factors. See the description of the return value for precise details of the way this is done.
expand.grid.rightLabel: Create a Data Frame from All Combinations of Factors
