extSoftVersion.description: Report versions of (external) third-party software used.

file.access.description: Utility function to access information about files on the user's file systems.

snippet: file.copy(${1:from}, ${2:to, overwrite = recursive, recursive = FALSE,copy.mode = TRUE, copy.date = FALSE})
displayText: file.copy(from, to, overwrite = recursive, recursive = FALSE,copy.mode = TRUE, copy.date = FALSE)
file.link.description: These functions provide a low-level interface to the computer's file system.

file.size.description: Utility function to extract information about files on the user's file systems.

file.path.description: Construct the path to a file from components in a platform-independent way.

file.show.snippet: file.show(${1:...}, ${2:header = rep("", nfiles),title = "R Information",delete.file = FALSE, pager = getOption("pager"),encoding = ""})
file.show.displayText: file.show(..., header = rep("", nfiles),title = "R Information",delete.file = FALSE, pager = getOption("pager"),encoding = "")
file.show.description: Display one or more (plain) text files, in a platform specific way, typically via a ‘pager’.
file.show.rightLabel: Display One or More Text Files

snippet: Reduce(${1:f}, ${2:x, init, right = FALSE, accumulate = FALSE})
displayText: Reduce(f, x, init, right = FALSE, accumulate = FALSE)
Find(f, x, right = FALSE, nomatch = NULL)
Position(f, x, right = FALSE, nomatch = NA_integer_)
Position.description: Reduce uses a binary function to successively combine the elements of a given vector and a possibly given initial value. Filter extracts the elements of a vector for which a predicate (logical) function gives true. Find and Position give the first or last such element and its position in the vector, respectively. Map applies a function to the corresponding elements of given vectors. Negate creates the negation of a given function.
Position.rightLabel: Common Higher-Order Functions in Functional Programming Languages

reg.finalizer.description: Registers an R function to be called upon garbage collection of object or (optionally) at the end of an R session.

snippet: find.package(${1:package}, ${2:lib.loc = NULL, quiet = FALSE, verbose = getOption("verbose"))})
displayText: find.package(package, lib.loc = NULL, quiet = FALSE, verbose = getOption("verbose"))
path.package.description: Find the paths to one or more packages.

findInterval.displayText: findInterval(x, vec, rightmost.closed = FALSE, all.inside = FALSE)
findInterval.description: Given a vector of non-decreasing breakpoints in vec, find the interval containing each element of x; i.e., if i <- findInterval(x,v), for each index j in x v[i[j]] ≤ x[j] < v[i[j] + 1] where v[0] := - Inf, v[N+1] := + Inf, and N <- length(v). At the two boundaries, the returned index may differ by 1, depending on the optional arguments rightmost.closed and all.inside.

is.nan.description: is.finite and is.infinite return a vector of the same length as x, indicating which elements are finite (not infinite and not missing) or infinite.

force.description: Forces the evaluation of a function argument.

forceAndCall.description: Call a function with a specified number of leading arguments forced before the call if the function is a closure.
forceAndCall.rightLabel: Call a function with Some Arguments Forced

snippet: .C(${1:.NAME}, ${2:..., NAOK = FALSE, DUP = TRUE, PACKAGE, ENCODING})
.Fortran(${1:.NAME}, ${2:..., NAOK = FALSE, DUP = TRUE, PACKAGE, ENCODING})
displayText: .C(.NAME, ..., NAOK = FALSE, DUP = TRUE, PACKAGE, ENCODING)
.Fortran(.NAME, ..., NAOK = FALSE, DUP = TRUE, PACKAGE, ENCODING)
.Fortran.description: Functions to make calls to compiled code that has been loaded into R.

formals.description: Get or set the formal arguments of a function.
formals.rightLabel: Access to and Manipulation of the Formal Arguments

snippet: format(${1:x}, ${2:trim = FALSE, digits = NULL, nsmall = 0L, justify = c("left", "right", "centre", "none"), width = NULL, na.encode = TRUE, scientific = NA, big.mark = "", big.interval = 3L, small.mark = "", small.interval = 5L, decimal.mark = getOption("OutDec"), zero.print = NULL, drop0trailing = FALSE, ...})
displayText: format(x, trim = FALSE, digits = NULL, nsmall = 0L, justify = c("left", "right", "centre", "none"), width = NULL, na.encode = TRUE, scientific = NA, big.mark = "", big.interval = 3L, small.mark = "", small.interval = 5L, decimal.mark = getOption("OutDec"), zero.print = NULL, drop0trailing = FALSE, ...)
format.description: Format an R object for pretty printing.

format.info.description: Information is returned on how format(x, digits, nsmall) would be formatted.

snippet: library(${1:package}, ${2:help, pos = 2, lib.loc = NULL,character.only = FALSE, logical.return = FALSE,warn.conflicts = TRUE, quietly = FALSE,verbose = getOption("verbose"))})
require(${1:package}, ${2:lib.loc = NULL, quietly = FALSE,warn.conflicts = TRUE,character.only = FALSE})
displayText: library(package, help, pos = 2, lib.loc = NULL,character.only = FALSE, logical.return = FALSE,warn.conflicts = TRUE, quietly = FALSE,verbose = getOption("verbose"))
require(package, lib.loc = NULL, quietly = FALSE,warn.conflicts = TRUE,character.only = FALSE)
require.description: library and require load and attach add-on packages.

format.pval.description: format.pval is intended for formatting p-values.

summary.2.description: summary is a generic function used to produce result summaries of the results of various model fitting functions. The function invokes particular methods which depend on the class of the first argument.

snippet: formatC(${1:x}, ${2:digits = NULL, width = NULL,format = NULL, flag = "", mode = NULL,big.mark = "", big.interval = 3L,small.mark = "", small.interval = 5L,decimal.mark = getOption("OutDec"),preserve.width = "individual", zero.print = NULL,drop0trailing = FALSE)})

prettyNum(${1:x}, ${2:big.mark = "", big.interval = 3L,small.mark= "", small.interval = 5L,decimal.mark = getOption("OutDec"), input.d.mark = decimal.mark,preserve.width = c("common", "individual", "none"),zero.print = NULL, drop0trailing = FALSE, is.cmplx = NA,...})
displayText: formatC(x, digits = NULL, width = NULL,format = NULL, flag = "", mode = NULL,big.mark = "", big.interval = 3L,small.mark = "", small.interval = 5L,decimal.mark = getOption("OutDec"),preserve.width = "individual", zero.print = NULL,drop0trailing = FALSE)

prettyNum(x, big.mark = "", big.interval = 3L,small.mark= "", small.interval = 5L,decimal.mark = getOption("OutDec"), input.d.mark = decimal.mark,preserve.width = c("common", "individual", "none"),zero.print = NULL, drop0trailing = FALSE, is.cmplx = NA,...)
.format.zeros.description: Formatting numbers individually and flexibly, formatC() using C style format specifications.

formatDL.snippet: formatDL(${1:x}, ${2:y, style = c("table", "list"), width = 0.9 * getOption("width"), indent = NULL})
formatDL.displayText: formatDL(x, y, style = c("table", "list"), width = 0.9 * getOption("width"), indent = NULL)
formatDL.description: Format vectors of items and their descriptions as 2-column tables or LaTeX-style description lists.

gcinfo.description: A call of gc causes a garbage collection to take place. gcinfo sets a flag so that automatic collection is either silent (verbose = FALSE) or prints memory usage statistics (verbose = TRUE).

gc.time.description: This function reports the time spent in garbage collection so far in the R session while GC timing was enabled.
gc.time.rightLabel: Report Time Spent in Garbage Collection

gctorture2.description: Provokes garbage collection on (nearly) every memory allocation. Intended to ferret out memory protection bugs. Also makes R run very slowly, unfortunately.

getDLLRegisteredRoutines.description: This function allows us to query the set of routines in a DLL that are registered with R to enhance dynamic lookup, error handling when calling native routines, and potentially security in the future. This function provides a description of each of the registered routines in the DLL for the different interfaces, i.e. .C, .Call, .Fortran and .External.
getDLLRegisteredRoutines.rightLabel: Reflectance Information for C/Fortran routines in a DLL

geterrmessage.description: stop stops execution of the current expression and executes an error action.

packageEvent.description: These functions allow users to set actions to be taken before packages are attached/detached and namespaces are (un)loaded.
packageEvent.rightLabel: Functions to Get and Set Hooks for Load, Attach, Detach and Unload

getNativeSymbolInfo.description: This finds and returns a description of one or more dynamically loaded or ‘exported’ built-in native symbols. For each name, it returns information about the name of the symbol, the library in which it is located and, if available, the number of arguments it expects and by which interface it should be called (i.e .Call, .C, .Fortran, or .External). Additionally, it returns the address of the symbol and this can be passed to other C routines. Specifically, this provides a way to explicitly share symbols between different dynamically loaded package libraries. Also, it provides a way to query where symbols were resolved, and aids diagnosing strange behavior associated with dynamic resolution.
getNativeSymbolInfo.rightLabel: Obtain a Description of one or more Native (C/Fortran) Symbols

getOption.description: Allow the user to set and examine a variety of global options which affect the way in which R computes and displays its results.

getTaskCallbackNames.description: This provides a way to get the names (or identifiers) for the currently registered task callbacks that are invoked at the conclusion of each top-level task. These identifiers can be used to remove a callback.
getTaskCallbackNames.rightLabel: Query the Names of the Current Internal Top-Level Task Callbacks

gettextf.description: A wrapper for the C function sprintf, that returns a character vector containing a formatted combination of text and variable values.

setwd.description: getwd returns an absolute filepath representing the current working directory of the R process; setwd(dir) is used to set the working directory to dir.

gl.snippet: gl(${1:n}, ${2:k, length = n*k, labels = seq_len(n), ordered = FALSE)})
gl.displayText: gl(n, k, length = n*k, labels = seq_len(n), ordered = FALSE)
gl.description: Generate factors by specifying the pattern of their levels.

snippet: grep(${1:pattern}, ${2:x, ignore.case = FALSE, perl = FALSE, value = FALSE, fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE, invert = FALSE})
grepl(${1:pattern}, ${2:x, ignore.case = FALSE, perl = FALSE,fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE})
sub(${1:pattern}, ${2:replacement, x, ignore.case = FALSE, perl = FALSE,fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE})
gsub(${1:pattern}, ${2:replacement, x, ignore.case = FALSE, perl = FALSE, fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE})
regexpr(${1:pattern}, ${2:text, ignore.case = FALSE, perl = FALSE,fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE})
gregexpr(${1:pattern}, ${2:text, ignore.case = FALSE, perl = FALSE, fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE})
regexec(${1:pattern}, ${2:text, ignore.case = FALSE,fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE})
displayText: grep(pattern, x, ignore.case = FALSE, perl = FALSE, value = FALSE, fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE, invert = FALSE)
grepl(pattern, x, ignore.case = FALSE, perl = FALSE,fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE)
sub(pattern, replacement, x, ignore.case = FALSE, perl = FALSE,fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE)
gsub(pattern, replacement, x, ignore.case = FALSE, perl = FALSE, fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE)
regexpr(pattern, text, ignore.case = FALSE, perl = FALSE,fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE)
gregexpr(pattern, text, ignore.case = FALSE, perl = FALSE, fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE)
regexec(pattern, text, ignore.case = FALSE,fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE)
regexec.description: grep, grepl, regexpr, gregexpr and regexec search for matches to argument pattern within each element of a character vector: they differ in the format of and amount of detail in the results.

grepRaw.snippet: grepRaw(${1:pattern}, ${2:x, offset = 1L, ignore.case = FALSE,value = FALSE, fixed = FALSE, all = FALSE, invert = FALSE})
grepRaw.displayText: grepRaw(pattern, x, offset = 1L, ignore.case = FALSE,value = FALSE, fixed = FALSE, all = FALSE, invert = FALSE)
grepRaw.description: grepRaw searches for substring pattern matches within a raw vector x.

grouping.description: grouping returns a permutation which rearranges its first argument such that identical values are adjacent to each other. Also returned as attributes are the group-wise partitioning and the maximum group size.

gzcon.displayText: gzcon(con, level = 6, allowNonCompressed = TRUE, text = FALSE)
gzcon.description: gzcon provides a modified connection that wraps an existing connection, and decompresses reads or compresses writes through that connection. Standard gzip headers are assumed.

snippet: iconv(${1:x}, ${2:from = "", to = "", sub = NA, mark = TRUE, toRaw = FALSE})
displayText: iconv(x, from = "", to = "", sub = NA, mark = TRUE, toRaw = FALSE)
iconvlist.description: This uses system facilities to convert a character vector between encodings: the ‘i’ stands for ‘internationalization’.

icuGetCollate.description: Controls the way collation is done by ICU (an optional part of the R build).

identical.snippet: identical(${1:x}, ${2:y, num.eq = TRUE, single.NA = TRUE, attrib.as.set = TRUE,ignore.bytecode = TRUE, ignore.environment = FALSE})
identical.displayText: identical(x, y, num.eq = TRUE, single.NA = TRUE, attrib.as.set = TRUE,ignore.bytecode = TRUE, ignore.environment = FALSE)
identical.description: The safe and reliable way to test two objects for being exactly equal. It returns TRUE in this case, FALSE in every other case.

identity.description: A trivial identity function returning its argument.

ifelse.description: ifelse returns a value with the same shape as test which is filled with elements selected from either yes or no depending on whether the element of test is TRUE or FALSE.

interaction.displayText: interaction(..., drop = FALSE, sep = ".", lex.order = FALSE)
interaction.description: interaction computes a factor which represents the interaction of the given factors. The result of interaction is always unordered.

interactive.description: Return TRUE when R is being used interactively and FALSE otherwise.

is.element.description: Performs set union, intersection, (asymmetric!) difference, equality and membership on two vectors.

print.2.description: Compute the lengths and values of runs of equal values in a vector – or the reverse operation.

invisible.description: Return a (temporarily) invisible copy of an object.
invisible.rightLabel: Change the Print Mode to Invisible

is.recursive.description: is.atomic returns TRUE if x is of an atomic type (or NULL) and FALSE otherwise.
is.recursive.rightLabel: Is an Object Atomic or Recursive?

is.primitive.description: Checks whether its argument is a (primitive) function.
is.primitive.rightLabel: Is an Object of Type (Primitive) Function?

is.language.description: is.language returns TRUE if x is a variable name, a call, or an expression.
is.language.rightLabel: Is an Object a Language Object?

is.object.description: A function rather for internal use. It returns TRUE if the object x has the R internal OBJECT bit set, and FALSE otherwise. The OBJECT bit is set when a "class" attribute is added and removed when that attribute is removed, so this is a very efficient way to check if an object has a class attribute. (S4 objects always should.)

is.R.rightLabel: Are we using R, rather than S?

is.single.description: is.single reports an error. There are no single precision values in R.
is.single.rightLabel: Is an Object of Single Precision Type?

is.unsorted.description: Test if an object is not sorted (in increasing order), without the cost of sorting it.
is.unsorted.rightLabel: Test if an Object is Not Sorted

snippet: ISOdatetime(${1:year}, ${2:month, day, hour, min, sec, tz = ""})
ISOdate(${1:year}, ${2:month, day, hour = 12, min = 0, sec = 0, tz = "GMT"})
displayText: ISOdatetime(year, month, day, hour, min, sec, tz = "")
ISOdate(year, month, day, hour = 12, min = 0, sec = 0, tz = "GMT")
ISOdate.description: Convenience wrappers to create date-times from numeric representations.
ISOdate.rightLabel: Date-time Conversion Functions from Numeric Representations

isSymmetric.description: Generic function to test if object is symmetric or not. Currently only a matrix method is implemented, where a complex matrix Z must be “Hermitian” for isSymmetric(Z) to be true.
isSymmetric.rightLabel: Test if a Matrix or other Object is Symmetric (Hermitian)

displayText: ! xx & yx && yx | yx || yxor(x, y)
isTRUE.description: These operators act on raw, logical and number-like vectors.

jitter.description: Add a small amount of noise to a numeric vector.

julian.description: Extract the weekday, month or quarter, or the Julian time (days since some origin). These are generic functions: the methods for the internal date-time classes are documented here.
julian.rightLabel: Extract Parts of a POSIXt or Date Object

displayText: kappa(z, exact = FALSE,norm = NULL, method = c("qr", "direct"), ...)
.kappa_tri(z, exact = FALSE, LINPACK = TRUE, norm = NULL, ...)
rcond.description: The condition number of a regular (square) matrix is the product of the norm of the matrix and the norm of its inverse (or pseudo-inverse), and hence depends on the kind of matrix-norm.
rcond.rightLabel: Compute or Estimate the Condition Number of a Matrix

kronecker.description: Computes the generalised kronecker product of two arrays, X and Y.

snippet: svd(${1:x}, ${2:nu = min(n, p), nv = min(n, p), LINPACK = FALSE})
La.svd(${1:x}, ${2:nu = min(n, p), nv = min(n, p)})
displayText: svd(x, nu = min(n, p), nv = min(n, p), LINPACK = FALSE)
La.svd(x, nu = min(n, p), nv = min(n, p)
La.svd.description: Compute the singular-value decomposition of a rectangular matrix.
La.svd.rightLabel: Singular Value Decomposition of a Matrix

labels.description: Find a suitable set of labels from an object for use in printing or plotting, for example. A generic function.

displayText: sapply(X, FUN, ..., simplify = TRUE, USE.NAMES = TRUE)
simplify2array.description: lapply returns a list of the same length as X, each element of which is the result of applying FUN to the corresponding element of X.
simplify2array.rightLabel: Apply a Function over a List or Vector

La_version.description: Report the version of LAPACK in use.

Sys.setlocale.description: Get details of or set aspects of the locale for the R process.
Sys.setlocale.rightLabel: Query or Set Aspects of the Locale

length.description: Get or set the length of vectors (including lists) and factors, and of any other R object for which a method has been defined.

lengths.description: Get the length of each element of a list or atomic vector (is.atomic) as an integer or numeric vector.
lengths.rightLabel: Lengths of List or Vector Elements

levels.description: levels provides access to the levels attribute of a variable. The first form returns the value of the levels of its argument and the second sets the attribute.

libcurlVersion.description: Report version of libcurl in use.

.dynLibs.description: Load the specified file of compiled code if it has not been loaded already, or unloads it.

licence.description: The license terms under which R is distributed.

list2env.snippet: list2env(${1:x}, ${2:envir = NULL, parent = parent.frame(), hash = (length(x) > 100), size = max(29L, length(x)})
list2env.displayText: list2env(x, envir = NULL, parent = parent.frame(), hash = (length(x) > 100), size = max(29L, length(x))
list2env.description: From a named list x, create an environment containing all list components as objects, or “multi-assign” from x into a pre-existing environment.
list2env.rightLabel: From A List, Build or Add To an Environment

load.description: Reload datasets written with the function save.

Sys.localeconv.description: Get details of the numerical and monetary representations in the current locale.
Sys.localeconv.rightLabel:
Find Details of the Numerical and Monetary Representations
in the Current Locale

upper.tri.description: Returns a matrix of logicals the same size of a given matrix with entries TRUE in the lower or upper triangle.
upper.tri.rightLabel: Lower and Upper Triangular Part of a Matrix

snippet: ls(${1:name}, ${2:pos = -1L, envir = as.environment(pos), all.names = FALSE, pattern, sorted = TRUE)})
objects(${1:name}, ${2:pos= -1L, envir = as.environment(pos),all.names = FALSE, pattern, sorted = TRUE)})
displayText: ls(name, pos = -1L, envir = as.environment(pos), all.names = FALSE, pattern, sorted = TRUE)
objects(name, pos= -1L, envir = as.environment(pos),all.names = FALSE, pattern, sorted = TRUE)
objects.description: ls and objects return a vector of character strings giving the names of the objects in the specified environment. When invoked with no argument at the top level prompt, ls shows what data sets and functions a user has defined. When invoked with no argument inside a function, ls returns the names of the function's local variables: this is useful in conjunction with browser.

make.names.description: Make syntactically valid names out of character vectors.

make.unique.description: Makes the elements of a character vector unique by appending sequence numbers to duplicates.

mapply.snippet: mapply(${1:FUN}, ${2:..., MoreArgs = NULL, SIMPLIFY = TRUE, USE.NAMES = TRUE})
mapply.displayText: mapply(FUN, ..., MoreArgs = NULL, SIMPLIFY = TRUE, USE.NAMES = TRUE)
mapply.description: mapply is a multivariate version of sapply. mapply applies FUN to the first elements of each ... argument, the second elements, the third elements, and so on. Arguments are recycled if necessary.
mapply.rightLabel: Apply a Function to Multiple List or Vector Arguments

margin.table.description: For a contingency table in array form, compute the sum of table entries for a given index.

mat.or.vec.description: mat.or.vec creates an nr by nc zero matrix if nc is greater than 1, and a zero vector of length nr if nc equals 1.
mat.or.vec.rightLabel: Create a Matrix or a Vector

match.displayText: match(x, table, nomatch = NA_integer_, incomparables = NULL)
match.description: match returns a vector of the positions of (first) matches of its first argument in its second.

match.arg.description: match.arg matches arg against a table of candidate values as specified by choices, where NULL means to take the first one.

match.call.snippet: match.call(${1:definition = sys.function(${1:sys.parent(${1:))}, ${2:call = sys.call(sys.parent()), expand.dots = TRUE, envir = parent.frame(2L})
match.call.displayText: match.call(definition = sys.function(sys.parent()), call = sys.call(sys.parent()), expand.dots = TRUE, envir = parent.frame(2L)
match.call.description: match.call returns a call in which all of the specified arguments are specified by their full names.

match.fun.description: When called inside functions that take a function as argument, extract the desired function object while avoiding undesired matching to objects of other types.
match.fun.rightLabel: Extract a Function Specified by Name

pmin.int.description: Returns the (parallel) maxima and minima of the input values.

max.col.description: Find the maximum position for each row of a matrix, breaking ties at random.

mean.description: Generic function for the (trimmed) arithmetic mean.

memDecompress.description: In-memory compression or decompression for raw vectors.

memory.profile.description: Lists the usage of the cons cells by SEXPREC type.
memory.profile.rightLabel: Profile the Usage of Cons Cells

snippet: merge(${1:x}, ${2:y, by = intersect(names(x), names(y)),by.x = by, by.y = by, all = FALSE, all.x = all, all.y = all,sort = TRUE, suffixes = c(".x",".y"),incomparables = NULL, ...})
displayText: merge(x, y, by = intersect(names(x), names(y)),by.x = by, by.y = by, all = FALSE, all.x = all, all.y = all,sort = TRUE, suffixes = c(".x",".y"),incomparables = NULL, ...)
merge.description: Merge two data frames by common columns or row names, or do other versions of database join operations.

.makeMessage.description: Generate a diagnostic message from its arguments.

missing.description: missing can be used to test whether a value was specified as an argument to a function.
missing.rightLabel: Does a Formal Argument have a Value?

mode.description: Get or set the type or storage mode of an object.

names.description: Functions to get or set the names of an object.

nargs.description: When used inside a function body, nargs returns the number of arguments supplied to that function, including positional arguments left blank.
nargs.rightLabel: The Number of Arguments to a Function

displayText: nchar(x, type = "chars", allowNA = FALSE, keepNA = FALSE)
nzchar.description: nchar takes a character vector as an argument and returns a vector whose elements contain the sizes of the corresponding elements of x.
nzchar.rightLabel: Count the Number of Characters (or Bytes or Width)

NROW.description: nrow and ncol return the number of rows or columns present in x. NCOL and NROW do the same treating a vector as 1-column matrix.
NROW.rightLabel: The Number of Rows/Columns of an Array

NextMethod.description: R possesses a simple generic function mechanism which can be used for an object-oriented style of programming. Method dispatch takes place based on the class(es) of the first argument to the generic function or of the object supplied as an argument to UseMethod or NextMethod.

nlevels.description: Return the number of levels which its argument has.
nlevels.rightLabel: The Number of Levels of a Factor

norm.description: Computes a matrix norm of x using LAPACK. The norm can be the one ("O") norm, the infinity ("I") norm, the Frobenius ("F") norm, the maximum modulus ("M") among elements of a matrix, or the “spectral” or "2"-norm, as determined by the value of type.
norm.rightLabel: Compute the Norm of a Matrix

normalizePath.description: Convert file paths to canonical form for the platform, to display them in a user-understandable form and so that relative and absolute paths can be compared.
normalizePath.rightLabel: Express File Paths in Canonical Form

.NotYetUsed.description: In order to pinpoint missing functionality, the R core team uses these functions for missing R functions and not yet used arguments of existing R functions (which are typically there for compatibility purposes).
.NotYetUsed.rightLabel: Not Yet Implemented Functions and Unused Arguments

OlsonNames.description: Information about time zones in R. Sys.timezone returns the name of the current time zone.

on.exit.description: on.exit records the expression given as its argument as needing to be executed when the current function exits (either naturally or as the result of an error). This is useful for resetting graphical parameters or performing other cleanup actions.

snippet: sort.list(${1:x}, ${2:partial = NULL, na.last = TRUE, decreasing = FALSE,method = c("shell", "quick", "radix"})
displayText: sort.list(x, partial = NULL, na.last = TRUE, decreasing = FALSE,method = c("shell", "quick", "radix")
sort.list.description: order returns a permutation which rearranges its first argument into ascending or descending order, breaking ties by further arguments. sort.list is the same, using only one argument. See the examples for how to use these functions to sort data frames, etc.

outer.description: The outer product of the arrays X and Y is the array A with dimension c(dim(X), dim(Y)) where element A[c(arrayindex.x, arrayindex.y)]   = FUN(X[arrayindex.x], Y[arrayindex.y], ...).

258.description: Open parenthesis, (, and open brace, {, are .Primitive functions in R.

parent.frame.description: These functions provide access to environments (‘frames’ in S terminology) associated with functions further up the calling stack.
parent.frame.rightLabel: Functions to Access the Function Call Stack

parse.snippet: parse(${1:file = ""}, ${2:n = NULL, text = NULL, prompt = "?",keep.source = getOption("keep.source"), srcfile,encoding = "unknown")})
parse.displayText: parse(file = "", n = NULL, text = NULL, prompt = "?",keep.source = getOption("keep.source"), srcfile,encoding = "unknown")
parse.description: parse returns the parsed but unevaluated expressions in a list.

paste0.description: Concatenate vectors after converting to character.

path.expand.description: Expand a path name, for example by replacing a leading tilde by the user's home directory (if defined on that platform).

pcre_config.description: Report some of the configuration options of the version of PCRE in use in this R session.

pmatch.displayText: pmatch(x, table, nomatch = NA_integer_, duplicates.ok = FALSE)
pmatch.description: pmatch seeks matches for the elements of its first argument among those of its second.

polyroot.description: Find zeros of a real or complex polynomial.
polyroot.rightLabel: Find Zeros of a Real or Complex Polynomial

pos.to.env.description: Returns the environment at a specified position in the search path.
pos.to.env.rightLabel: Convert Positions in the Search Path to Environments

snippet: pretty(${1:x}, ${2:n = 5, min.n = n %/% 3,shrink.sml = 0.75, high.u.bias = 1.5, u5.bias = .5 + 1.5*high.u.bias, eps.correct = 0, ...})
displayText: pretty(x, n = 5, min.n = n %/% 3,shrink.sml = 0.75, high.u.bias = 1.5, u5.bias = .5 + 1.5*high.u.bias, eps.correct = 0, ...)
pretty.description: Compute a sequence of about n+1 equally spaced ‘round’ values which cover the range of the values in x. The values are chosen so that they are 1, 2 or 5 times a power of 10.

.Primitive.description: .Primitive looks up by name a ‘primitive’ (internally implemented) function.

snippet: print(${1:x}, ${2:digits = getOption("digits"), quote = FALSE,na.print = "", zero.print = "0", justify = "none", ...)})
displayText: print(x, quote = FALSE, max.levels = NULL,width = getOption("width"), ...)
print(x, digits = getOption("digits"), quote = FALSE,na.print = "", zero.print = "0", justify = "none", ...)
print.3.description: print prints its argument and returns it invisibly (via invisible(x)). It is a generic function which means that new printing methods can be easily added for new classes.

print.4.snippet: print(${1:x}, ${2:..., digits = NULL,quote = FALSE, right = TRUE, row.names = TRUE})
print.4.displayText: print(x, ..., digits = NULL,quote = FALSE, right = TRUE, row.names = TRUE)

print.5.snippet: print(${1:x}, ${2:digits = NULL, quote = TRUE,na.print = NULL, print.gap = NULL, right = FALSE,max = NULL, useSource = TRUE, ...})
print.5.displayText: print(x, digits = NULL, quote = TRUE,na.print = NULL, print.gap = NULL, right = FALSE,max = NULL, useSource = TRUE, ...)
print.5.description: print.default is the default method of the generic print function which prints its argument.

proc.time.description: proc.time determines how much real and CPU time (in seconds) the currently running R process has already taken.

prmatrix.snippet: prmatrix(${1:x}, ${2:rowlab =, collab =, quote = TRUE, right = FALSE, na.print = NULL, ...})
prmatrix.displayText: prmatrix(x, rowlab =, collab =, quote = TRUE, right = FALSE, na.print = NULL, ...)
prmatrix.description: An earlier method for printing matrices, provided for S compatibility.

prod.description: prod returns the product of all the values present in its arguments.

prop.table.description: This is really sweep(x, margin, margin.table(x, margin), "/") for newbies, except that if margin has length zero, then one gets x/sum(x).
prop.table.rightLabel: Express Table Entries as Fraction of Marginal Table

q.description: The function quit or its alias q terminate the current R session.

qr.R.description: Returns the original matrix from which the object was constructed or the components of the decomposition.
qr.R.rightLabel: Reconstruct the Q, R, or X Matrices from a QR Object

R.home.description: Return the R home directory, or the full path to a component of the R installation.

R.Version.description: R.Version() provides detailed information about the version of R running.

set.seed.description: .Random.seed is an integer vector, containing the random number generator (RNG) state for random number generation in R. It can be saved and restored, but should not be altered by the user.

range.description: range returns a vector containing the minimum and maximum of all the given arguments.

rank.description: Returns the sample ranks of the values in a vector. Ties (i.e., equal values) and missing values can be handled in several ways.

rapply.snippet: rapply(${1:object}, ${2:f, classes = "ANY", deflt = NULL, how = c("unlist", "replace", "list"), ...)})
rapply.displayText: rapply(object, f, classes = "ANY", deflt = NULL, how = c("unlist", "replace", "list"), ...)
rapply.description: rapply is a recursive version of lapply.
rapply.rightLabel: Recursively Apply a Function to a List

snippet: read.dcf(${1:file}, ${2:fields = NULL, all = FALSE, keep.white = NULL})
write.dcf(${1:x}, ${2:file = "", append = FALSE,indent = 0.1 * getOption("width"),width = 0.9 * getOption("width"),keep.white = NULL})
displayText: read.dcf(file, fields = NULL, all = FALSE, keep.white = NULL)
write.dcf(x, file = "", append = FALSE,indent = 0.1 * getOption("width"),width = 0.9 * getOption("width"),keep.white = NULL)
write.dcf.description: Reads or writes an R object from/to a file in Debian Control File format.
write.dcf.rightLabel: Read and Write Data in DCF Format

snippet: readBin(${1:con}, ${2:what, n = 1L, size = NA_integer_, signed = TRUE,endian = .Platform$endian})
writeBin(${1:object}, ${2:con, size = NA_integer_, endian = .Platform$endian, useBytes = FALSE})
displayText: readBin(con, what, n = 1L, size = NA_integer_, signed = TRUE,endian = .Platform$endian)
writeBin(object, con, size = NA_integer_, endian = .Platform$endian, useBytes = FALSE)
writeBin.description: Read binary data from or write binary data to a connection or raw vector.
writeBin.rightLabel: Transfer Binary Data To and From Connections

snippet: writeChar(${1:object}, ${2:con, nchars = nchar(object, type = "chars"),eos = "", useBytes = FALSE)})
displayText: writeChar(object, con, nchars = nchar(object, type = "chars"),eos = "", useBytes = FALSE)
writeChar.description: Transfer character strings to and from connections, without assuming they are null-terminated on the connection.
writeChar.rightLabel: Transfer Character Strings To and From Connections

readline.description: readline reads a line from the terminal (in interactive use).
readline.rightLabel: Read a Line from the Terminal

readLines.snippet: readLines(${1:con = stdin(${1:)}, ${2:n = -1L, ok = TRUE, warn = TRUE,encoding = "unknown", skipNul = FALSE})
readLines.displayText: readLines(con = stdin(), n = -1L, ok = TRUE, warn = TRUE,encoding = "unknown", skipNul = FALSE)
readLines.description: Read some or all text lines from a connection.
readLines.rightLabel: Read Text Lines from a Connection

snippet: saveRDS(${1:object}, ${2:file = "", ascii = FALSE, version = NULL,compress = TRUE, refhook = NULL})
displayText: saveRDS(object, file = "", ascii = FALSE, version = NULL,compress = TRUE, refhook = NULL)
readRDS.description: Functions to write a single R object to a file, and to restore it.

readRenviron.description: Read as file such as ‘.Renviron’ or ‘Renviron.site’ in the format described in the help for Startup, and set environment variables as defined in the file.
readRenviron.rightLabel: Set Environment Variables from a File

Recall.description: Recall is used as a placeholder for the name of the function in which it is called. It allows the definition of recursive functions which still work after being renamed, see example below.

regmatches.description: Extract or replace matched substrings from match data obtained by regexpr, gregexpr or regexec.

snippet: remove(${1:...}, ${2:list = character(), pos = -1, envir = as.environment(pos), inherits = FALSE})
rm(${1:...}, ${2:list = character(), pos = -1, envir = as.environment(pos), inherits = FALSE})
displayText: remove(..., list = character(), pos = -1, envir = as.environment(pos), inherits = FALSE)
rm(..., list = character(), pos = -1, envir = as.environment(pos), inherits = FALSE)
rm.description: remove and rm can be used to remove objects. These can be specified successively as character strings, or in the character vector list, or through a combination of both. All objects thus specified will be removed.
rm.rightLabel: Remove Objects from a Specified Environment

rep_len.description: rep replicates the values in x. It is a generic function, and the (internal) default method is described here.
rep_len.rightLabel: Replicate Elements of Vectors and Lists

replace.description: replace replaces the values in x with indices given in list by those given in values. If necessary, the values in values are recycled.

retracemem.description: This function marks an object so that a message is printed whenever the internal code copies the object. It is a major cause of hard-to-predict memory use in R.

snippet: trace(${1:what}, ${2:tracer, exit, at, print, signature,where = topenv(parent.frame()), edit = FALSE})
displayText: trace(what, tracer, exit, at, print, signature,where = topenv(parent.frame()), edit = FALSE)
returnValue.description: A call to trace allows you to insert debugging code (e.g., a call to browser or recover) at chosen places in any function. A call to untrace cancels the tracing. Specified methods can be traced the same way, without tracing all calls to the function. Trace code can be any R expression. Tracing can be temporarily turned on or off globally by calling tracingState.
returnValue.rightLabel: Interactive Tracing and Debugging of Calls to a Function or Method

rev.description: rev provides a reversed version of its argument. It is generic function with a default method for vectors and one for dendrograms.

row.description: Returns a matrix of integers indicating their row number in a matrix-like object, or a factor indicating the row labels.

row.names.description: All data frames have a row names attribute, a character vector of length the number of rows with no duplicates nor missing values.
row.names.rightLabel: Get and Set Row Names for Data Frames

displayText: rowsum(x, group, reorder = TRUE, na.rm = FALSE, ...)
rowsum(x, group, reorder = TRUE, na.rm = FALSE, ...)
rowsum.description: Compute column sums across rows of a numeric matrix-like object for each level of a grouping variable. rowsum is generic, with a method for data frames and a default method for vectors and matrices.
rowsum.rightLabel: Give Column Sums of a Matrix or Data Frame, Based on a Grouping Variable

.libPaths.description: .libPaths gets/sets the library trees within which packages are looked for.

snippet: sample.int(${1:n}, ${2:size = n, replace = FALSE, prob = NULL})
displayText: sample(x, size, replace = FALSE, prob = NULL)
sample.int(n, size = n, replace = FALSE, prob = NULL)
sample.int.description: sample takes a sample of the specified size from the elements of x using either with or without replacement.

snippet: save(${1:...}, ${2:list = character(), file = stop("'file' must be specified"), ascii = FALSE, version = NULL, envir = parent.frame(), compress = isTRUE(!ascii), compression_level, eval.promises = TRUE, precheck = TRUE})
save.image(${1:file = ".RData"}, ${2:version = NULL, ascii = FALSE, compress = !ascii, safe = TRUE})
displayText: save(..., list = character(), file = stop("'file' must be specified"), ascii = FALSE, version = NULL, envir = parent.frame(), compress = isTRUE(!ascii), compression_level, eval.promises = TRUE, precheck = TRUE)
save.image(file = ".RData", version = NULL, ascii = FALSE, compress = !ascii, safe = TRUE)
save.image.description: save writes an external representation of R objects to the specified file. The objects can be read back from the file at a later date by using the function load or attach (or data in some cases).

scale.description: scale is generic function whose default method centers and/or scales the columns of a numeric matrix.
scale.rightLabel: Scaling and Centering of Matrix-like Objects

scan.snippet: scan(${1:file = ""}, ${2:what = double(), nmax = -1, n = -1, sep = "", quote = if(identical(sep, "\n")) "" else "'\"", dec = ".", skip = 0, nlines = 0, na.strings = "NA", flush = FALSE, fill = FALSE, strip.white = FALSE, quiet = FALSE, blank.lines.skip = TRUE, multi.line = TRUE, comment.char = "", allowEscapes = FALSE, fileEncoding = "", encoding = "unknown", text, skipNul = FALSE)})
scan.displayText: scan(file = "", what = double(), nmax = -1, n = -1, sep = "", quote = if(identical(sep, "\n")) "" else "'\"", dec = ".", skip = 0, nlines = 0, na.strings = "NA", flush = FALSE, fill = FALSE, strip.white = FALSE, quiet = FALSE, blank.lines.skip = TRUE, multi.line = TRUE, comment.char = "", allowEscapes = FALSE, fileEncoding = "", encoding = "unknown", text, skipNul = FALSE)
scan.description: Read data into a vector or list from the console or file.

searchpaths.description: Gives a list of attached packages (see library), and R objects, usually data.frames.
searchpaths.rightLabel: Give Search Path for R Objects

snippet: seq(${1:from = 1}, ${2:to = 1, by = ((to - from)/(length.out - 1)),length.out = NULL, along.with = NULL, ...)})
displayText: seq(from = 1, to = 1, by = ((to - from)/(length.out - 1)),length.out = NULL, along.with = NULL, ...)
seq_len.description: Generate regular sequences. seq is a standard generic with a default method. seq.int is a primitive which can be much faster but has a few restrictions. seq_along and seq_len are very fast primitives for two common cases.

seq.snippet: seq(${1:from}, ${2:to, by, length.out = NULL, along.with = NULL, ...})
seq.displayText: seq(from, to, by, length.out = NULL, along.with = NULL, ...)
seq.description: The method for seq for objects of class class "Date" representing calendar dates.

seq.1.snippet: seq(${1:from}, ${2:to, by, length.out = NULL, along.with = NULL, ...})
seq.1.displayText: seq(from, to, by, length.out = NULL, along.with = NULL, ...)
seq.1.description: The method for seq for date-time classes.

sequence.description: For each element of nvec the sequence seq_len(nvec[i]) is created. These are concatenated and the result returned.

snippet: serialize(${1:object}, ${2:connection, ascii, xdr = TRUE,version = NULL, refhook = NULL})
displayText: serialize(object, connection, ascii, xdr = TRUE,version = NULL, refhook = NULL)
unserialize.description: A simple low-level interface for serializing to connections.

displayText: setTimeLimit(cpu = Inf, elapsed = Inf, transient = FALSE)
setSessionTimeLimit.description: Functions to set CPU and/or elapsed time limits for top-level computations or the current session.
setSessionTimeLimit.rightLabel: Set CPU and/or Elapsed Time Limits

system.snippet: system(${1:command}, ${2:intern = FALSE, ignore.stdout = FALSE, ignore.stderr = FALSE, wait = TRUE, input = NULL, show.output.on.console = TRUE, minimized = FALSE, invisible = TRUE})
system.displayText: system(command, intern = FALSE, ignore.stdout = FALSE, ignore.stderr = FALSE, wait = TRUE, input = NULL, show.output.on.console = TRUE, minimized = FALSE, invisible = TRUE)
system.description: system invokes the OS command specified by command.

shQuote.description: Quote a string to be passed to an operating system shell.
shQuote.rightLabel: Quote Strings for Use in OS Shells

sign.description: sign returns a vector with the signs of the corresponding elements of x (the sign of a real number is 1, 0, or -1 if the number is positive, zero, or negative, respectively).

snippet: sink(${1:file = NULL}, ${2:append = FALSE, type = c("output", "message"), split = FALSE)})
displayText: sink(file = NULL, append = FALSE, type = c("output", "message"), split = FALSE)
sink.number.description: sink diverts R output to a connection (and stops such diversions).
sink.number.rightLabel: Send R Output to a File

slice.index.description: Returns a matrix of integers indicating the number of their slice in a given array.

socketSelect.description: Waits for the first of several socket connections to become available.

solve.description: This generic function solves the equation a %*% x = b for x, where b can be either a vector or a matrix.

snippet: sort.int(${1:x}, ${2:partial = NULL, na.last = NA, decreasing = FALSE, method = c("shell", "quick"), index.return = FALSE)})
displayText: sort.int(x, partial = NULL, na.last = NA, decreasing = FALSE, method = c("shell", "quick"), index.return = FALSE)
sort.int.description: Sort (or order) a vector or factor (partially) into ascending or descending order. For ordering along more than one variable, e.g., for sorting data frames, see order.

source.snippet: source(${1:file}, ${2:local = FALSE, echo = verbose, print.eval = echo, verbose = getOption("verbose"), prompt.echo = getOption("prompt"), max.deparse.length = 150, chdir = FALSE, encoding = getOption("encoding"), continue.echo = getOption("continue"), skip.echo = 0, keep.source = getOption("keep.source"})
source.displayText: source(file, local = FALSE, echo = verbose, print.eval = echo, verbose = getOption("verbose"), prompt.echo = getOption("prompt"), max.deparse.length = 150, chdir = FALSE, encoding = getOption("encoding"), continue.echo = getOption("continue"), skip.echo = 0, keep.source = getOption("keep.source")
source.description: source causes R to accept its input from the named file or URL or connection. Input is read and parsed from that file until the end of the file is reached, then the parsed expressions are evaluated sequentially in the chosen environment.
source.rightLabel: Read R Code from a File or a Connection

split.description: split divides the data in the vector x into the groups defined by f. The replacement forms replace values corresponding to such a division. unsplit reverses the effect of split.

stopifnot.description: If any of the expressions in ... are not all TRUE, stop is called, producing an error message indicating the first of the elements of ... which were not true.
stopifnot.rightLabel: Ensure the Truth of R Expressions

strrep.description: Repeat the character strings in a character vector a given number of times (i.e., concatenate the respective numbers of copies of the strings).
strrep.rightLabel: Repeat the Elements of a Character Vector

strsplit.snippet: strsplit(${1:x}, ${2:split, fixed = FALSE, perl = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE})
strsplit.displayText: strsplit(x, split, fixed = FALSE, perl = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE)
strsplit.description: Split the elements of a character vector x into substrings according to the matches to substring split within them.
strsplit.rightLabel: Split the Elements of a Character Vector

strtoi.description: Convert strings to integers according to the given base using the C function strtol, or choose a suitable base following the C rules.

strtrim.description: Trim character strings to specified display widths.
strtrim.rightLabel: Trim Character Strings to Specified Display Widths

structure.description: structure returns the given object with further attributes set.

strwrap.snippet: strwrap(${1:x}, ${2:width = 0.9 * getOption("width"), indent = 0,exdent = 0, prefix = "", simplify = TRUE, initial = prefix)})
strwrap.displayText: strwrap(x, width = 0.9 * getOption("width"), indent = 0,exdent = 0, prefix = "", simplify = TRUE, initial = prefix)
strwrap.description: Each character string in the input is first split into paragraphs (or lines containing whitespace only). The paragraphs are then formatted by breaking lines at word boundaries. The target columns for wrapping lines and the indentation of the first and all subsequent lines of a paragraph can be controlled independently.
strwrap.rightLabel: Wrap Character Strings to Format Paragraphs

subset.description: Return subsets of vectors, matrices or data frames which meet conditions.
subset.rightLabel: Subsetting Vectors, Matrices and Data Frames

substring.1.description: Extract or replace substrings in a character vector.

sum.description: sum returns the sum of all the values present in its arguments.

snippet: warning(${1:...}, ${2:call. = TRUE, immediate. = FALSE, noBreaks. = FALSE,domain = NULL})
displayText: warning(..., call. = TRUE, immediate. = FALSE, noBreaks. = FALSE,domain = NULL)
suppressWarnings.description: Generates a warning message that corresponds to its argument(s) and (optionally) the expression or function from which it was called.

sweep.displayText: sweep(x, MARGIN, STATS, FUN = "-", check.margin = TRUE, ...)
sweep.description: Return an array obtained from an input array by sweeping out a summary statistic.

switch.description: switch evaluates EXPR and accordingly chooses one of the further arguments (in ...).
switch.rightLabel: Select One of a List of Alternatives

Sys.Date.description: Sys.time and Sys.Date returns the system's idea of the current date with and without time.

Sys.getenv.description: Sys.getenv obtains the values of the environment variables.

Sys.getpid.description: Get the process ID of the R Session. It is guaranteed by the operating system that two R sessions running simultaneously will have different IDs, but it is possible that R sessions running at different times will have the same ID.
Sys.getpid.rightLabel: Get the Process ID of the R Session

Sys.glob.description: Function to do wildcard expansion (also known as ‘globbing’) on file paths.

Sys.readlink.description: Find out if a file path is a symbolic link, and if so what it is linked to, via the system call readlink.

Sys.unsetenv.description: Sys.setenv sets environment variables (for other processes called from within R or future calls to Sys.getenv from this R process).

Sys.setFileTime.description: Uses system calls to set the times on a file or directory.

Sys.sleep.description: Suspend execution of R expressions for a specified time interval.
Sys.sleep.rightLabel: Suspend Execution for a Time Interval

sys.source.snippet: sys.source(${1:file}, ${2:envir = baseenv(), chdir = FALSE, keep.source = getOption("keep.source.pkgs")})
sys.source.displayText: sys.source(file, envir = baseenv(), chdir = FALSE, keep.source = getOption("keep.source.pkgs")
sys.source.description: Parses expressions in the given file, and then successively evaluates them in the specified environment.
sys.source.rightLabel: Parse and Evaluate Expressions from a File

Sys.which.description: This is an interface to the system command which, or to an emulation on Windows.

system.file.description: Finds the full file names of files in packages etc.
system.file.rightLabel: Find Names of R System Files

unix.time.description: Return CPU (and other) times that expr used.

system2.snippet: system2(${1:command}, ${2:args = character(),stdout = "", stderr = "", stdin = "", input = NULL,env = character(), wait = TRUE,minimized = FALSE, invisible = TRUE})
system2.displayText: system2(command, args = character(),stdout = "", stderr = "", stdin = "", input = NULL,env = character(), wait = TRUE,minimized = FALSE, invisible = TRUE)
system2.description: system2 invokes the OS command specified by command.

t.description: Given a matrix or data.frame x, t returns the transpose of x.

tabulate.displayText: tabulate(bin, nbins = max(1, bin, na.rm = TRUE)
tabulate.description: tabulate takes the integer-valued vector bin and counts the number of times each integer occurs in it.

tapply.displayText: tapply(X, INDEX, FUN = NULL, ..., simplify = TRUE)
tapply.description: Apply a function to each cell of a ragged array, that is to each (non-empty) group of values given by a unique combination of the levels of certain factors.
tapply.rightLabel: Apply a Function Over a Ragged Array

taskCallbackManager.description: This provides an entirely S-language mechanism for managing callbacks or actions that are invoked at the conclusion of each top-level task. Essentially, we register a single R function from this manager with the underlying, native task-callback mechanism and this function handles invoking the other R callbacks under the control of the manager. The manager consists of a collection of functions that access shared variables to manage the list of user-level callbacks.
taskCallbackManager.rightLabel: Create an R-level Task Callback Manager

tempdir.description: tempfile returns a vector of character strings which can be used as names for temporary files.

displayText: textConnection(object, open = "r", local = FALSE, encoding = c("", "bytes", "UTF-8"))

topenv.description: Finding the top level environment from an environment envir and its enclosing environments.

toString.description: This is a helper function for format to produce a single character string describing an R object.
toString.rightLabel: Convert an R Object to a Character String

traceback.description: By default traceback() prints the call stack of the last uncaught error, i.e., the sequence of calls that lead to the error. This is useful when an error occurs with an unidentifiable error message. It can also be used to print the current stack or arbitrary lists of deparsed calls.

transform.description: transform is a generic function, which—at least currently—only does anything useful with data frames. transform.default converts its first argument to a data frame if possible and calls transform.data.frame.
transform.rightLabel: Transform an Object, for Example a Data Frame

trimws.description: Remove leading and/or trailing whitespace from character strings.

try.description: try is a wrapper to run an expression that might fail and allow the user's code to handle error-recovery.
try.rightLabel: Try an Expression Allowing Error Recovery

typeof.description: typeof determines the (R internal) type or storage mode of any object

displayText: unique(x, incomparables = FALSE, fromLast = FALSE,nmax = NA, ...)
unique(x, incomparables = FALSE, MARGIN = 1, fromLast = FALSE, ...)
unique(x, incomparables = FALSE, MARGIN = 1, fromLast = FALSE, ...)
unique.description: unique returns a vector, data frame or array like x but with duplicate elements/rows removed.

unlink.description: unlink deletes the file(s) or directories specified by x.

unlist.description: Given a list structure x, unlist simplifies it to produce a vector which contains all the atomic components which occur in x.

unname.description: Remove the names or dimnames attribute of an R object.

validEnc.description: Check if each element of a character vector is valid in its implied encoding.
validEnc.rightLabel: Check if a Character Vector is Validly Encoded

Vectorize.displayText: Vectorize(FUN, vectorize.args = arg.names, SIMPLIFY = TRUE,USE.NAMES = TRUE)
Vectorize.description: Vectorize creates a function wrapper that vectorizes the action of its argument FUN.

which.max.description: Determines the location, i.e., index of the (first) minimum or maximum of a numeric (or logical) vector.
which.max.rightLabel: Where is the Min() or Max() or first TRUE or FALSE ?

within.description: Evaluate an R expression in an environment constructed from data, possibly modifying (a copy of) the original data.
within.rightLabel: Evaluate an Expression in a Data Environment

withVisible.description: This function evaluates an expression, returning it in a two element list containing its value and a flag showing whether it would automatically print.
withVisible.rightLabel: Return both a value and its visibility

write.displayText: write(x, file = "data",ncolumns = if(is.character(x)) 1 else 5,append = FALSE, sep = " ")
write.description: The data (usually a matrix) x are written to file file. If x is a two-dimensional matrix you need to transpose it to get the columns in file the same as those in the internal representation.

writeLines.displayText: writeLines(text, con = stdout(), sep = "\n", useBytes = FALSE)
writeLines.description: Write text lines to a connection.

xtfrm.description: A generic auxiliary function that produces a numeric vector which will sort in the same order as x.
xtfrm.rightLabel: Auxiliary Function for Sorting and Ranking

zapsmall.description: zapsmall determines a digits argument dr for calling round(x, digits = dr) such that values close to zero (compared with the maximal absolute value) are ‘zapped’, i.e., treated as 0.

snippet: acf(${1:x}, ${2:lag.max = NULL,type = c("correlation", "covariance", "partial"),plot = TRUE, na.action = na.fail, demean = TRUE, ...)})
pacf(${1:x}, ${2:lag.max = NULL, plot = TRUE, na.action = na.fail,...})
ccf(${1:x}, ${2:y, lag.max = NULL, type = c("correlation", "covariance"),plot = TRUE, na.action = na.fail, ...)})
displayText: acf(x, lag.max = NULL,type = c("correlation", "covariance", "partial"),plot = TRUE, na.action = na.fail, demean = TRUE, ...)
pacf(x, lag.max = NULL, plot = TRUE, na.action = na.fail,...)
ccf(x, y, lag.max = NULL, type = c("correlation", "covariance"),plot = TRUE, na.action = na.fail, ...)
ccf.description: The function acf computes (and by default plots) estimates of the autocovariance or autocorrelation function. Function pacf is the function used for the partial autocorrelations. Function ccf computes the cross-correlation or cross-covariance of two univariate series.
ccf.rightLabel: Auto- and Cross- Covariance and -Correlation Function Estimation

acf2AR.description: Compute an AR process exactly fitting an autocorrelation function.

addmargins.description: For a given table one can specify which of the classifying factors to expand by one or more levels to hold margins to be calculated. One may for example form sums and means over the first dimension and medians over the second. The resulting table will then have two extra levels for the first dimension and one extra level for the second. The default is to sum over all margins in the table. Other possibilities may give results that depend on the order in which the margins are computed. This is flagged in the printed output from the function.
addmargins.rightLabel: Puts Arbitrary Margins on Multidimensional Tables or Arrays

BIC.description: Generic function calculating Akaike's ‘An Information Criterion’ for one or several fitted model objects for which a log-likelihood value can be obtained, according to the formula -2*log-likelihood + k*npar, where npar represents the number of parameters in the fitted model, and k = 2 for the usual AIC, or k = log(n) (n being the number of observations) for the so-called BIC or SBC (Schwarz's Bayesian criterion).

dendrapply.description: Apply function FUN to each node of a dendrogram recursively. When y <- dendrapply(x, fn), then y is a dendrogram of the same graph structure as x and for each node, y.node[j] <- FUN( x.node[j], ...) (where y.node[j] is an (invalid!) notation for the j-th node of y.
dendrapply.rightLabel: Apply a Function to All Nodes of a Dendrogram

# S3 methods for class 'SSD' and 'mlm'es.description: Functions to compute matrix of residual sums of squares and products, or the estimated variance matrix for multivariate linear models.

expand.model.frame.description: Evaluates new variables as if they had been part of the formula of the specified model. This ensures that the same na.action and subset arguments are applied and allows, for example, x to be recovered for a model using sin(x) as a predictor.

getCall.description: update will update and (by default) re-fit a model. It does this by extracting the call stored in the object, updating the call and (by default) evaluating that call. Sometimes it is useful to call update with only one argument, for example if the data frame has been corrected.

If data is a parameterized data frame or pframe object, its parameters attribute is returned. Otherwise the object is examined to see if it contains a call to a selfStart object whose initial attribute can be evaluated.

lines.2.description: Plotting method for objects inheriting from class "ts".

lm.snippet: lm(${1:formula}, ${2:data, subset, weights, na.action, method = "qr", model = TRUE, x = FALSE, y = FALSE, qr = TRUE, singular.ok = TRUE, contrasts = NULL, offset, ...})
lm.displayText: lm(formula, data, subset, weights, na.action, method = "qr", model = TRUE, x = FALSE, y = FALSE, qr = TRUE, singular.ok = TRUE, contrasts = NULL, offset, ...)
lm.description: lm is used to fit linear models. It can be used to carry out regression, single stratum analysis of variance and analysis of covariance (although aov may provide a more convenient interface for these).

snippet: lm.fit (${1:x}, ${2:y,offset = NULL, method = "qr", tol = 1e-7, singular.ok = TRUE, ...})
lm.wfit(${1:x}, ${2:y, w, offset = NULL, method = "qr", tol = 1e-7,singular.ok = TRUE, ...})
displayText: lm.fit (x, y,offset = NULL, method = "qr", tol = 1e-7, singular.ok = TRUE, ...)
lm.wfit(x, y, w, offset = NULL, method = "qr", tol = 1e-7,singular.ok = TRUE, ...)
.lm.fit.description: These are the basic computing engines called by lm used to fit linear models. These should usually not be used directly unless by experienced users. .lm.fit() is bare bone wrapper to the innermost QR-based C code, on which glm.fit and lsfit are based as well, for even more experienced users.

print.8.description: Extract or print loadings in factor analysis (or principal components analysis).

loess.snippet: loess(${1:formula}, ${2:data, weights, subset, na.action, model = FALSE,span = 0.75, enp.target, degree = 2,parametric = FALSE, drop.square = FALSE, normalize = TRUE,family = c("gaussian", "symmetric"),method = c("loess", "model.frame"),control = loess.control(...), ...)})
loess.displayText: loess(formula, data, weights, subset, na.action, model = FALSE,span = 0.75, enp.target, degree = 2,parametric = FALSE, drop.square = FALSE, normalize = TRUE,family = c("gaussian", "symmetric"),method = c("loess", "model.frame"),control = loess.control(...), ...)
loess.description: Fit a polynomial surface determined by one or more numerical predictors, using local fitting.

loess.control.snippet: loess.control(${1:surface = c(${1:"interpolate"}, ${2:"direct"),statistics = c("approximate", "exact", "none"),trace.hat = c("exact", "approximate"),cell = 0.2, iterations = 4, iterTrace = FALSE, ...)})
loess.control.displayText: loess.control(surface = c("interpolate", "direct"),statistics = c("approximate", "exact", "none"),trace.hat = c("exact", "approximate"),cell = 0.2, iterations = 4, iterTrace = FALSE, ...)
loess.control.description: Set control parameters for loess fits.

snippet: scatter.smooth(${1:x}, ${2:y = NULL, span = 2/3, degree = 1,family = c("symmetric", "gaussian"),xlab = NULL, ylab = NULL,ylim = range(y, pred$y, na.rm = TRUE),evaluation = 50, ..., lpars = list())})
displayText: scatter.smooth(x, y = NULL, span = 2/3, degree = 1,family = c("symmetric", "gaussian"),xlab = NULL, ylab = NULL,ylim = range(y, pred$y, na.rm = TRUE),evaluation = 50, ..., lpars = list())
loess.smooth(x, y, span = 2/3, degree = 1,family = c("symmetric", "gaussian"), evaluation = 50, ...)
loess.smooth.description: Plot and add a smooth curve computed by loess to a scatter plot.
loess.smooth.rightLabel: Scatter Plot with Smooth Curve Fitted by Loess

logLik.description: This function is generic; method functions can be written to handle specific classes of objects. Classes which have methods for this function include: "glm", "lm", "nls" and "Arima". Packages contain methods for other classes, such as "fitdistr", "negbin" and "polr" in package MASS, "multinom" in package nnet and "gls", "gnls" "lme" and others in package nlme.

loglin.snippet: loglin(${1:table}, ${2:margin, start = rep(1, length(table)), fit = FALSE, eps = 0.1, iter = 20, param = FALSE, print = TRUE})
loglin.displayText: loglin(table, margin, start = rep(1, length(table)), fit = FALSE, eps = 0.1, iter = 20, param = FALSE, print = TRUE)
loglin.description: loglin is used to fit log-linear models to multidimensional contingency tables by Iterative Proportional Fitting.

lowess.snippet: lowess(${1:x}, ${2:y = NULL, f = 2/3, iter = 3, delta = 0.01 * diff(range(x))})
lowess.displayText: lowess(x, y = NULL, f = 2/3, iter = 3, delta = 0.01 * diff(range(x))
lowess.description: This function performs the computations for the LOWESS smoother which uses locally-weighted polynomial regression (see the references).

ls.diag.description: Computes basic statistics, including standard errors, t- and p-values for the regression coefficients.
ls.diag.rightLabel: Compute Diagnostics for lsfit Regression Results

ls.print.description: Computes basic statistics, including standard errors, t- and p-values for the regression coefficients and prints them if print.it is TRUE.

lsfit.snippet: lsfit(${1:x}, ${2:y, wt = NULL, intercept = TRUE, tolerance = 1e-07,yname = NULL})
lsfit.displayText: lsfit(x, y, wt = NULL, intercept = TRUE, tolerance = 1e-07,yname = NULL)
lsfit.description: The least squares estimate of b in the model

mad.snippet: mad(${1:x}, ${2:center = median(x), constant = 1.4826, na.rm = FALSE,low = FALSE, high = FALSE)})
mad.displayText: mad(x, center = median(x), constant = 1.4826, na.rm = FALSE,low = FALSE, high = FALSE)
mad.description: Compute the median absolute deviation, i.e., the (lo-/hi-) median of the absolute deviations from the median, and (by default) adjust by a factor for asymptotically normal consistency.

mahalanobis.description: Returns the squared Mahalanobis distance of all rows in x and the vector mu = center with respect to Sigma = cov. This is (for vector x) defined as

make.link.description: This function is used with the family functions in glm(). Given the name of a link, it returns a link function, an inverse link function, the derivative dmu/deta and a function for domain checking.
make.link.rightLabel: Create a Link for GLM Families

makepredictcall.description: A utility to help model.frame.default create the right matrices when predicting from models with terms like (univariate) poly or ns.

snippet: poly(${1:x}, ${2:..., degree = 1, coefs = NULL, raw = FALSE, simple = FALSE})
displayText: poly(x, ..., degree = 1, coefs = NULL, raw = FALSE, simple = FALSE)
polym(..., degree = 1, coefs = NULL, raw = FALSE)
predict.2.description: Returns or evaluates orthogonal polynomials of degree 1 to degree over the specified set of points x: these are all orthogonal to the constant polynomial of degree 0. Alternatively, evaluate raw polynomials.

manova.description: A class for the multivariate analysis of variance.

mantelhaen.test.snippet: mantelhaen.test(${1:x}, ${2:y = NULL, z = NULL,alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),correct = TRUE, exact = FALSE, conf.level = 0.95)})
mantelhaen.test.displayText: mantelhaen.test(x, y = NULL, z = NULL,alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),correct = TRUE, exact = FALSE, conf.level = 0.95)
mantelhaen.test.description: Performs a Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel chi-squared test of the null that two nominal variables are conditionally independent in each stratum, assuming that there is no three-way interaction.
mantelhaen.test.rightLabel: Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Chi-Squared Test for Count Data

snippet: mauchly.test(${1:object}, ${2:Sigma = diag(nrow = p), T = Thin.row(proj(M) - proj(X)), M = diag(nrow = p), X = ~0, idata = data.frame(index = seq_len(p)), ...)})
displayText: mauchly.test(object, Sigma = diag(nrow = p), T = Thin.row(proj(M) - proj(X)), M = diag(nrow = p), X = ~0, idata = data.frame(index = seq_len(p)), ...)
mauchly.test.description: Tests whether a Wishart-distributed covariance matrix (or transformation thereof) is proportional to a given matrix.

mcnemar.test.description: Performs McNemar's chi-squared test for symmetry of rows and columns in a two-dimensional contingency table.
mcnemar.test.rightLabel: McNemar's Chi-squared Test for Count Data

medpolish.displayText: medpolish(x, eps = 0.01, maxiter = 10, trace.iter = TRUE,na.rm = FALSE)
medpolish.description: Fits an additive model using Tukey's median polish procedure.

model.weights.description: Returns the response, offset, subset, weights or other special components of a model frame passed as optional arguments to model.frame.
model.weights.rightLabel: Extract Components from a Model Frame

snippet: model.matrix(${1:object}, ${2:data = environment(object), contrasts.arg = NULL, xlev = NULL, ...)})
displayText: model.matrix(object, data = environment(object), contrasts.arg = NULL, xlev = NULL, ...)
model.matrix.description: model.matrix creates a design (or model) matrix, e.g., by expanding factors to a set of dummary variables (depending on the contrasts) and expanding interactions similarly.

model.tables.description: Computes summary tables for model fits, especially complex aov fits.
model.tables.rightLabel: Compute Tables of Results from an Aov Model Fit

snippet: monthplot(${1:x}, ${2:labels = NULL, times = time(x), phase = cycle(x), ylab = deparse(substitute(x)), ...})

monthplot(${1:x}, ${2:labels = 1L:12L,ylab = deparse(substitute(x)),times = seq_along(x),phase = (times - 1L)%%length(labels) + 1L, base = mean,axes = TRUE, type = c("l", "h"), box = TRUE,add = FALSE,col = par("col"), lty = par("lty"), lwd = par("lwd"),col.base = col, lty.base = lty, lwd.base = lwd, ...)})
displayText: monthplot(x, labels = NULL, ylab = choice, choice = "seasonal",...)
monthplot(x, labels = NULL, ylab = choice, choice = "sea", ...)
monthplot(x, labels = NULL, times = time(x), phase = cycle(x), ylab = deparse(substitute(x)), ...)

monthplot(x, labels = 1L:12L,ylab = deparse(substitute(x)),times = seq_along(x),phase = (times - 1L)%%length(labels) + 1L, base = mean,axes = TRUE, type = c("l", "h"), box = TRUE,add = FALSE,col = par("col"), lty = par("lty"), lwd = par("lwd"),col.base = col, lty.base = lty, lwd.base = lwd, ...)
monthplot.description: These functions plot seasonal (or other) subseries of a time series. For each season (or other category), a time series is plotted.
monthplot.rightLabel: Plot a Seasonal or other Subseries from a Time Series

mood.test.description: Performs Mood's two-sample test for a difference in scale parameters.

na.action.description: Extract information on the NA action used to create an object.

na.contiguous.description: Find the longest consecutive stretch of non-missing values in a time series object. (In the event of a tie, the first such stretch.)
na.contiguous.rightLabel: Find Longest Contiguous Stretch of non-NAs

na.pass.description: These generic functions are useful for dealing with NAs in e.g., data frames. na.fail returns the object if it does not contain any missing values, and signals an error otherwise. na.omit returns the object with incomplete cases removed. na.pass returns the object unchanged.

napredict.description: Use missing value information to adjust residuals and predictions.

naprint.description: Use missing value information to report the effects of an na.action.

nextn.description: nextn returns the smallest integer, greater than or equal to n, which can be obtained as a product of powers of the values contained in factors. nextn is intended to be used to find a suitable length to zero-pad the argument of fft to so that the transform is computed quickly. The default value for factors ensures this.

nlm.snippet: nlm(${1:f}, ${2:p, ..., hessian = FALSE, typsize = rep(1, length(p)),fscale = 1, print.level = 0, ndigit = 12, gradtol = 1e-6,stepmax = max(1000 * sqrt(sum((p/typsize)^2)), 1000),steptol = 1e-6, iterlim = 100, check.analyticals = TRUE})
nlm.displayText: nlm(f, p, ..., hessian = FALSE, typsize = rep(1, length(p)),fscale = 1, print.level = 0, ndigit = 12, gradtol = 1e-6,stepmax = max(1000 * sqrt(sum((p/typsize)^2)), 1000),steptol = 1e-6, iterlim = 100, check.analyticals = TRUE)
nlm.description: This function carries out a minimization of the function f using a Newton-type algorithm. See the references for details.

nlminb.snippet: nlminb(${1:start}, ${2:objective, gradient = NULL, hessian = NULL, ..., scale = 1, control = list(), lower = -Inf, upper = Inf)})
nlminb.displayText: nlminb(start, objective, gradient = NULL, hessian = NULL, ..., scale = 1, control = list(), lower = -Inf, upper = Inf)
nlminb.description: Unconstrained and box-constrained optimization using PORT routines.

nls.snippet: nls(${1:formula}, ${2:data, start, control, algorithm,trace, subset, weights, na.action, model,lower, upper, ...})
nls.displayText: nls(formula, data, start, control, algorithm,trace, subset, weights, na.action, model,lower, upper, ...)
nls.description: Determine the nonlinear (weighted) least-squares estimates of the parameters of a nonlinear model.

nls.control.displayText: nls.control(maxiter = 50, tol = 1e-05, minFactor = 1/1024,printEval = FALSE, warnOnly = FALSE)
nls.control.description: Allow the user to set some characteristics of the nls nonlinear least squares algorithm.

NLSstAsymptotic.description: Fits the asymptotic regression model, in the form b0 +    b1*(1-exp(-exp(lrc) * x) to the xy data. This can be used as a building block in determining starting estimates for more complicated models.

NLSstClosestX.description: Use inverse linear interpolation to approximate the x value at which the function represented by xy is equal to yval.

NLSstLfAsymptote.description: Provide an initial guess at the horizontal asymptote on the left side (i.e., small values of x) of the graph of y versus x from the xy object. Primarily used within initial functions for self-starting nonlinear regression models.
NLSstLfAsymptote.rightLabel: Horizontal Asymptote on the Left Side

NLSstRtAsymptote.description: Provide an initial guess at the horizontal asymptote on the right side (i.e., large values of x) of the graph of y versus x from the xy object. Primarily used within initial functions for self-starting nonlinear regression models.
NLSstRtAsymptote.rightLabel: Horizontal Asymptote on the Right Side

nobs.description: Extract the number of ‘observations’ from a model fit. This is principally intended to be used in computing BIC (see AIC).
nobs.rightLabel: Extract the Number of Observations from a Fit.

numericDeriv.description: numericDeriv numerically evaluates the gradient of an expression.

offset.description: An offset is a term to be added to a linear predictor, such as in a generalised linear model, with known coefficient 1 rather than an estimated coefficient.
offset.rightLabel: Include an Offset in a Model Formula

oneway.test.displayText: oneway.test(formula, data, subset, na.action, var.equal = FALSE)
oneway.test.description: Test whether two or more samples from normal distributions have the same means. The variances are not necessarily assumed to be equal.
oneway.test.rightLabel: Test for Equal Means in a One-Way Layout

snippet: optim(${1:par}, ${2:fn, gr = NULL, ...,method = c("Nelder-Mead", "BFGS", "CG", "L-BFGS-B", "SANN", "Brent"),lower = -Inf, upper = Inf,control = list(), hessian = FALSE})
displayText: optim(par, fn, gr = NULL, ...,method = c("Nelder-Mead", "BFGS", "CG", "L-BFGS-B", "SANN", "Brent"),lower = -Inf, upper = Inf,control = list(), hessian = FALSE)
optimHess(par, fn, gr = NULL, ..., control = list()
optimHess.description: General-purpose optimization based on Nelder–Mead, quasi-Newton and conjugate-gradient algorithms. It includes an option for box-constrained optimization and simulated annealing.

snippet: optimize(${1:f = }, ${2:interval = ,..., lower = min(interval), upper = max(interval), maximum = FALSE, tol = .Machine$double.eps^0.25})
optimise(${1:f = }, ${2:interval = ,..., lower = min(interval), upper = max(interval), maximum = FALSE, tol = .Machine$double.eps^0.25})
displayText: optimize(f = , interval = ,..., lower = min(interval), upper = max(interval), maximum = FALSE, tol = .Machine$double.eps^0.25)
optimise(f = , interval = ,..., lower = min(interval), upper = max(interval), maximum = FALSE, tol = .Machine$double.eps^0.25)
optimise.description: The function optimize searches the interval from lower to upper for a minimum or maximum of the function f with respect to its first argument.

p.adjust.methods# c.description: Given a set of p-values, returns p-values adjusted using one of several methods.

pairwise.prop.test.description: Calculate pairwise comparisons between pairs of proportions with correction for multiple testing

pairwise.t.test.snippet: pairwise.t.test(${1:x}, ${2:g, p.adjust.method = p.adjust.methods,pool.sd = !paired, paired = FALSE,alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),...)})
pairwise.t.test.displayText: pairwise.t.test(x, g, p.adjust.method = p.adjust.methods,pool.sd = !paired, paired = FALSE,alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),...)
pairwise.t.test.description: Calculate pairwise comparisons between group levels with corrections for multiple testing

pairwise.table.description: Creates table of p values for pairwise comparisons with corrections for multiple testing.
pairwise.table.rightLabel: Tabulate p values for pairwise comparisons

pairwise.wilcox.test.description: Calculate pairwise comparisons between group levels with corrections for multiple testing.

pbirthday.description: Computes answers to a generalised birthday paradox problem. pbirthday computes the probability of a coincidence and qbirthday computes the smallest number of observations needed to have at least a specified probability of coincidence.

plclust.snippet: plclust(${1:tree}, ${2:hang = 0.1, unit = FALSE, level = FALSE, hmin = 0,square = TRUE, labels = NULL, plot. = TRUE,axes = TRUE, frame.plot = FALSE, ann = TRUE,main = "", sub = NULL, xlab = NULL, ylab = "Height"})

plclust.description: These functions are provided for compatibility with older versions of R only, and may be defunct as soon as the next release.

plot.2.description: Plot method for objects of class "acf".

plot.3.description: The plot method for density objects.
plot.3.rightLabel: Plot Method for Kernel Density Estimation
