plot.4.displayText: plot(x, predicted.values = NA, intervals = TRUE,separator = TRUE, col = 1, col.predicted = 2,col.intervals = 4, col.separator = 1, lty = 1,lty.predicted = 1, lty.intervals = 1, lty.separator = 3,ylab = "Observed / Fitted",main = "Holt-Winters filtering",ylim = NULL, ...)
plot.4.description: Produces a chart of the original time series along with the fitted values. Optionally, predicted values (and their confidence bounds) can also be plotted.

plot.5.snippet: plot(${1:x}, ${2:which = c(1:3, 5),caption = list("Residuals vs Fitted", "Normal Q-Q", "Scale-Location", "Cook's distance", "Residuals vs Leverage", expression("Cook's dist vs Leverage" * h[ii] / (1 - h[ii]))), panel = if(add.smooth) panel.smooth else points, sub.caption = NULL, main = "", ask = prod(par("mfcol")) < length(which) && dev.interactive(), ..., id.n = 3, labels.id = names(residuals(x)), cex.id = 0.75, qqline = TRUE, cook.levels = c(0.5, 1.0), add.smooth = getOption("add.smooth"), label.pos = c(4,2), cex.caption = 1, cex.oma.main = 1.25})
plot.5.displayText: plot(x, which = c(1:3, 5),caption = list("Residuals vs Fitted", "Normal Q-Q", "Scale-Location", "Cook's distance", "Residuals vs Leverage", expression("Cook's dist vs Leverage" * h[ii] / (1 - h[ii]))), panel = if(add.smooth) panel.smooth else points, sub.caption = NULL, main = "", ask = prod(par("mfcol")) < length(which) && dev.interactive(), ..., id.n = 3, labels.id = names(residuals(x)), cex.id = 0.75, qqline = TRUE, cook.levels = c(0.5, 1.0), add.smooth = getOption("add.smooth"), label.pos = c(4,2), cex.caption = 1, cex.oma.main = 1.25)
plot.5.description: Six plots (selectable by which) are currently available: a plot of residuals against fitted values, a Scale-Location plot of sqrt(| residuals |) against fitted values, a Normal Q-Q plot, a plot of Cook's distances versus row labels, a plot of residuals against leverages, and a plot of Cook's distances against leverage/(1-leverage). By default, the first three and 5 are provided.
plot.5.rightLabel: Plot Diagnostics for an lm Object

plot.6.description: Plot ridge functions for projection pursuit regression fit.
plot.6.rightLabel: Plot Ridge Functions for Projection Pursuit Regression Fit

plot.7.description: Displays a series of plots of the profile t function and interpolated confidence intervals for the parameters in a nonlinear regression model that has been fit with nls and profiled with profile.nls.

plot.spec.coherency.description: Plotting method for objects of class "spec". For multivariate time series it plots the marginal spectra of the series or pairs plots of the coherency and phase of the cross-spectra.

plot.8.description: Methods for objects of class stl, typically the result of stl. The plot method does a multiple figure plot with some flexibility.

poisson.test.description: Performs an exact test of a simple null hypothesis about the rate parameter in Poisson distribution, or for the ratio between two rate parameters.

power.description: Creates a link object based on the link function η = μ ^ λ.

power.anova.test.description: Compute power of test or determine parameters to obtain target power.
power.anova.test.rightLabel: Power Calculations for Balanced One-Way Analysis of Variance Tests

power.prop.test.displayText: power.prop.test(n = NULL, p1 = NULL, p2 = NULL, sig.level = 0.05,power = NULL,alternative = c("two.sided", "one.sided"),strict = FALSE, tol = .Machine$double.eps^0.25)
power.prop.test.description: Compute the power of the two-sample test for proportions, or determine parameters to obtain a target power.
power.prop.test.rightLabel: Power Calculations for Two-Sample Test for Proportions

power.t.test.rightLabel: Power calculations for one and two sample t tests

PP.test.description: Computes the Phillips-Perron test for the null hypothesis that x has a unit root against a stationary alternative.

ppoints.description: Generates the sequence of probability points (1:m - a)/(m + (1-a)-a) where m is either n, if length(n)==1, or length(n).

ppr.description: Fit a projection pursuit regression model.

predict.description: predict is a generic function for predictions from the results of various model fitting functions. The function invokes particular methods which depend on the class of the first argument.

predict.5.description: Forecast from models fitted by arima.

predict.6.displayText: predict(object, newdata = NULL,type = c("link", "response", "terms"),se.fit = FALSE, dispersion = NULL, terms = NULL,na.action = na.pass, ...)
predict.6.description: Obtains predictions and optionally estimates standard errors of those predictions from a fitted generalized linear model object.

predict.7.description: Computes predictions and prediction intervals for models fitted by the Holt-Winters method.
predict.7.rightLabel: Prediction Function for Fitted Holt-Winters Models

predict.8.snippet: predict(${1:object}, ${2:newdata, se.fit = FALSE, scale = NULL, df = Inf,interval = c("none", "confidence", "prediction"),level = 0.95, type = c("response", "terms"),terms = NULL, na.action = na.pass,pred.var = res.var/weights, weights = 1, ...})

predict.8.description: Predicted values based on linear model object.
predict.8.rightLabel: Predict method for Linear Model Fits

predict.9.displayText: predict(object, newdata = NULL, se = FALSE,na.action = na.pass, ...)
predict.9.description: Predictions from a loess fit, optionally with standard errors.

predict.10.snippet: predict(${1:object}, ${2:newdata , se.fit = FALSE, scale = NULL, df = Inf,interval = c("none", "confidence", "prediction"),level = 0.95, ...)})
predict.10.displayText: predict(object, newdata , se.fit = FALSE, scale = NULL, df = Inf,interval = c("none", "confidence", "prediction"),level = 0.95, ...)
predict.10.description: predict.nls produces predicted values, obtained by evaluating the regression function in the frame newdata. If the logical se.fit is TRUE, standard errors of the predictions are calculated. If the numeric argument scale is set (with optional df), it is used as the residual standard deviation in the computation of the standard errors, otherwise this is extracted from the model fit. Setting intervals specifies computation of confidence or prediction (tolerance) intervals at the specified level.
predict.10.rightLabel: Predicting from Nonlinear Least Squares Fits

predict.11.description: Predict a smoothing spline fit at new points, return the derivative if desired. The predicted fit is linear beyond the original data.

StructTS.description: Fit a structural model for a time series by maximum likelihood.

preplot.description: Compute an object to be used for plots relating to the given model object.

print.9.description: Printing objects of class "htest" or "power.htest", respectively, by simple print methods.
print.9.rightLabel: Print Methods for Hypothesis Tests and Power Calculation Objects

xtabs.description: Create a contingency table (optionally a sparse matrix) from cross-classifying factors, usually contained in a data frame, using a formula interface.

printCoefmat.description: Utility function to be used in higher-level print methods, such as those for summary.lm, summary.glm and anova. The goal is to provide a flexible interface with smart defaults such that often, only x needs to be specified.

profile.description: Investigates behavior of objective function near the solution represented by fitted.

profile.1.description: Investigates the profile log-likelihood function for a fitted model of class "nls".

proj.description: proj returns a matrix or list of matrices giving the projections of the data onto the terms of a linear model. It is most frequently used for aov models.

promax.description: These functions ‘rotate’ loading matrices in factor analysis.

prop.test.snippet: prop.test(${1:x}, ${2:n, p = NULL,alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),conf.level = 0.95, correct = TRUE)})
prop.test.displayText: prop.test(x, n, p = NULL,alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),conf.level = 0.95, correct = TRUE)
prop.test.description: prop.test can be used for testing the null that the proportions (probabilities of success) in several groups are the same, or that they equal certain given values.
prop.test.rightLabel: Test of Equal or Given Proportions

prop.trend.test.description: Performs chi-squared test for trend in proportions, i.e., a test asymptotically optimal for local alternatives where the log odds vary in proportion with score. By default, score is chosen as the group numbers.

snippet: ptukey(${1:q}, ${2:nmeans, df, nranges = 1, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE})
qtukey(${1:p}, ${2:nmeans, df, nranges = 1, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE})

qtukey(p, nmeans, df, nranges = 1, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE)
qtukey.description: Functions of the distribution of the studentized range, R/s, where R is the range of a standard normal sample and df*s^2 is independently distributed as chi-squared with df degrees of freedom, see pchisq.

snippet: qqnorm(${1:y}, ${2:ylim, main = "Normal Q-Q Plot", xlab = "Theoretical Quantiles", ylab = "Sample Quantiles", plot.it = TRUE, datax = FALSE, ...})
qqline(${1:y}, ${2:datax = FALSE, distribution = qnorm, probs = c(0.25, 0.75), qtype = 7, ...)})
qqplot(${1:x}, ${2:y, plot.it = TRUE, xlab = deparse(substitute(x)), ylab = deparse(substitute(y)), ...})

qqline(y, datax = FALSE, distribution = qnorm, probs = c(0.25, 0.75), qtype = 7, ...)
qqplot(x, y, plot.it = TRUE, xlab = deparse(substitute(x)), ylab = deparse(substitute(y)), ...)
qqplot.description: qqnorm is a generic function the default method of which produces a normal QQ plot of the values in y. qqline adds a line to a “theoretical”, by default normal, quantile-quantile plot which passes through the probs quantiles, by default the first and third quartiles.

quade.test.description: Performs a Quade test with unreplicated blocked data.

snippet: quantile(${1:x}, ${2:probs = seq(0, 1, 0.25), na.rm = FALSE, names = TRUE, type = 7, ...)})
displayText: quantile(x, probs = seq(0, 1, 0.25), na.rm = FALSE, names = TRUE, type = 7, ...)
quantile.1.description: The generic function quantile produces sample quantiles corresponding to the given probabilities. The smallest observation corresponds to a probability of 0 and the largest to a probability of 1.

r2dtable.description: Generate random 2-way tables with given marginals using Patefield's algorithm.

rect.hclust.snippet: rect.hclust(${1:tree}, ${2:k = NULL, which = NULL, x = NULL, h = NULL,border = 2, cluster = NULL})
rect.hclust.displayText: rect.hclust(tree, k = NULL, which = NULL, x = NULL, h = NULL,border = 2, cluster = NULL)
rect.hclust.description: Draws rectangles around the branches of a dendrogram highlighting the corresponding clusters. First the dendrogram is cut at a certain level, then a rectangle is drawn around selected branches.

relevel.description: The levels of a factor are re-ordered so that the level specified by ref is first and the others are moved down. This is useful for contr.treatment contrasts which take the first level as the reference.

reorder.description: reorder is a generic function. The "default" method treats its first argument as a categorical variable, and reorders its levels based on the values of a second variable, usually numeric.

reorder.1.description: A method for the generic function reorder.

replications.description: Returns a vector or a list of the number of replicates for each term in the formula.

snippet: reshape(${1:data}, ${2:varying = NULL, v.names = NULL, timevar = "time",idvar = "id", ids = 1:NROW(data),times = seq_along(varying[[1]]),drop = NULL, direction, new.row.names = NULL,sep = ".",split = if (sep == "") {list(regexp = "[A-Za-z][0-9]", include = TRUE)})

} else {list(regexp = sep, include = FALSE, fixed = TRUE)})
} else {list.description: This function reshapes a data frame between ‘wide’ format with repeated measurements in separate columns of the same record and ‘long’ format with the repeated measurements in separate records.

resid.description: residuals is a generic function which extracts model residuals from objects returned by modeling functions.

runmed.snippet: runmed(${1:x}, ${2:k, endrule = c("median", "keep", "constant"), algorithm = NULL, print.level = 0)})
runmed.displayText: runmed(x, k, endrule = c("median", "keep", "constant"), algorithm = NULL, print.level = 0)
runmed.description: Compute running medians of odd span. This is the ‘most robust’ scatter plot smoothing possible. For efficiency (and historical reason), you can use one of two different algorithms giving identical results.
runmed.rightLabel: Running Medians – Robust Scatter Plot Smoothing

rWishart.description: Generate n random matrices, distributed according to the Wishart distribution with parameters Sigma and df, W_p(Sigma, df).

screeplot.displayText: screeplot(x, npcs = min(10, length(x$sdev)),type = c("barplot", "lines"),main = deparse(substitute(x)), ...)
screeplot.description: screeplot.default plots the variances against the number of the principal component. This is also the plot method for classes "princomp" and "prcomp".

sd.description: This function computes the standard deviation of the values in x. If na.rm is TRUE then missing values are removed before computation proceeds.

displayText: se.contrast(object, contrast.obj, coef = contr.helmert(ncol(contrast))[, 1], data = NULL, ...)
se.contrast.description: Returns the standard errors for one or more contrasts in an aov object.
se.contrast.rightLabel: Standard Errors for Contrasts in Model Terms

setNames.description: This is a convenience function that sets the names on an object and returns the object. It is most useful at the end of a function definition where one is creating the object to be returned and would prefer not to store it under a name just so the names can be assigned.
setNames.rightLabel: Set the Names in an Object

shapiro.test.description: Performs the Shapiro-Wilk test of normality.

sigma.description: Extract the estimated standard deviation of the errors, the “residual standard deviation” (misnomed also “residual standard error”, e.g., in summary.lm()'s output, from a fitted model).

simulate.description: Simulate one or more responses from the distribution corresponding to a fitted model object.

smooth.snippet: smooth(${1:x}, ${2:kind = c("3RS3R", "3RSS", "3RSR", "3R", "3", "S"), twiceit = FALSE, endrule = c("Tukey", "copy"), do.ends = FALSE})
smooth.displayText: smooth(x, kind = c("3RS3R", "3RSS", "3RSR", "3R", "3", "S"), twiceit = FALSE, endrule = c("Tukey", "copy"), do.ends = FALSE)

smooth.spline.displayText: smooth.spline(x, y = NULL, w = NULL, df, spar = NULL, cv = FALSE,all.knots = FALSE, nknots = .nknots.smspl,keep.data = TRUE, df.offset = 0, penalty = 1,control.spar = list(), tol = 1e-6 * IQR(x)
smooth.spline.description: Fits a cubic smoothing spline to the supplied data.

smoothEnds.description: Smooth end points of a vector y using subsequently smaller medians and Tukey's end point rule at the very end. (of odd span),

sortedXyData.description: This is a constructor function for the class of sortedXyData objects. These objects are mostly used in the initial function for a self-starting nonlinear regression model, which will be of the selfStart class.

spectrum.description: The spectrum function estimates the spectral density of a time series.

spec.ar.snippet: spec.ar(${1:x}, ${2:n.freq, order = NULL, plot = TRUE, na.action = na.fail,method = "yule-walker", ...})
spec.ar.displayText: spec.ar(x, n.freq, order = NULL, plot = TRUE, na.action = na.fail,method = "yule-walker", ...)
spec.ar.description: Fits an AR model to x (or uses the existing fit) and computes (and by default plots) the spectral density of the fitted model.
spec.ar.rightLabel: Estimate Spectral Density of a Time Series from AR Fit

spec.pgram.snippet: spec.pgram(${1:x}, ${2:spans = NULL, kernel, taper = 0.1, pad = 0, fast = TRUE, demean = FALSE, detrend = TRUE, plot = TRUE, na.action = na.fail, ...})
spec.pgram.displayText: spec.pgram(x, spans = NULL, kernel, taper = 0.1, pad = 0, fast = TRUE, demean = FALSE, detrend = TRUE, plot = TRUE, na.action = na.fail, ...)
spec.pgram.description: spec.pgram calculates the periodogram using a fast Fourier transform, and optionally smooths the result with a series of modified Daniell smoothers (moving averages giving half weight to the end values).
spec.pgram.rightLabel:
Estimate Spectral Density of a Time Series by a Smoothed
Periodogram

spec.taper.description: Apply a cosine-bell taper to a time series.
spec.taper.rightLabel: Taper a Time Series by a Cosine Bell

snippet: spline(${1:x}, ${2:y = NULL, n = 3*length(x), method = "fmm", xmin = min(x), xmax = max(x), xout, ties = mean)})
displayText: spline(x, y = NULL, n = 3*length(x), method = "fmm", xmin = min(x), xmax = max(x), xout, ties = mean)
splinefunH.description: Perform cubic (or Hermite) spline interpolation of given data points, returning either a list of points obtained by the interpolation or a function performing the interpolation.

SSasymp.description: This selfStart model evaluates the asymptotic regression function and its gradient. It has an initial attribute that will evaluate initial estimates of the parameters Asym, R0, and lrc for a given set of data.

SSasympOff.description: This selfStart model evaluates an alternative parametrization of the asymptotic regression function and the gradient with respect to those parameters. It has an initial attribute that creates initial estimates of the parameters Asym, lrc, and c0.
SSasympOff.rightLabel: Self-Starting Nls Asymptotic Regression Model with an Offset

SSasympOrig.description: This selfStart model evaluates the asymptotic regression function through the origin and its gradient. It has an initial attribute that will evaluate initial estimates of the parameters Asym and lrc for a given set of data.
SSasympOrig.rightLabel: Self-Starting Nls Asymptotic Regression Model through the Origin

SSbiexp.description: This selfStart model evaluates the biexponential model function and its gradient. It has an initial attribute that creates initial estimates of the parameters A1, lrc1, A2, and lrc2.

SSfol.description: This selfStart model evaluates the first-order compartment function and its gradient. It has an initial attribute that creates initial estimates of the parameters lKe, lKa, and lCl.

SSfpl.description: This selfStart model evaluates the four-parameter logistic function and its gradient. It has an initial attribute that will evaluate initial estimates of the parameters A, B, xmid, and scal for a given set of data.

SSgompertz.description: This selfStart model evaluates the Gompertz growth model and its gradient. It has an initial attribute that creates initial estimates of the parameters Asym, b2, and b3.

SSlogis.description: This selfStart model evaluates the logistic function and its gradient. It has an initial attribute that creates initial estimates of the parameters Asym, xmid, and scal.

SSmicmen.description: This selfStart model evaluates the Michaelis-Menten model and its gradient. It has an initial attribute that will evaluate initial estimates of the parameters Vm and K

SSweibull.description: This selfStart model evaluates the Weibull model for growth curve data and its gradient. It has an initial attribute that will evaluate initial estimates of the parameters Asym, Drop, lrc, and pwr for a given set of data.
SSweibull.rightLabel: Self-Starting Nls Weibull Growth Curve Model

stat.anova.displayText: stat.anova(table, test = c("Rao","LRT", "Chisq", "F", "Cp"), scale, df.scale, n)
stat.anova.description: This is a utility function, used in lm and glm methods for anova(..., test != NULL) and should not be used by the average user.

step.rightLabel: Choose a model by AIC in a Stepwise Algorithm

terms.1.snippet: terms(${1:x}, ${2:specials = NULL, abb = NULL, data = NULL, neg.out = TRUE,keep.order = FALSE, simplify = FALSE, ...,allowDotAsName = FALSE})
terms.1.displayText: terms(x, specials = NULL, abb = NULL, data = NULL, neg.out = TRUE,keep.order = FALSE, simplify = FALSE, ...,allowDotAsName = FALSE)
terms.1.description: This function takes a formula and some optional arguments and constructs a terms object. The terms object can then be used to construct a model.matrix.
terms.1.rightLabel: Construct a terms Object from a Formula

toeplitz.description: Forms a symmetric Toeplitz matrix given its first row.

ts.union.description: Bind time series which have a common frequency. ts.union pads with NAs to the total time coverage, ts.intersect restricts to the time covered by all the series.
ts.union.rightLabel: Bind Two or More Time Series

ts.plot.description: Plot several time series on a common plot. Unlike plot.ts the series can have a different time bases, but they should have the same frequency.

tsdiag.description: A generic function to plot time-series diagnostics.

tsSmooth.description: Performs fixed-interval smoothing on a univariate time series via a state-space model. Fixed-interval smoothing gives the best estimate of the state at each time point based on the whole observed series.
tsSmooth.rightLabel: Use Fixed-Interval Smoothing on Time Series

TukeyHSD.description: Create a set of confidence intervals on the differences between the means of the levels of a factor with the specified family-wise probability of coverage. The intervals are based on the Studentized range statistic, Tukey's ‘Honest Significant Difference’ method.

uniroot.snippet: uniroot(${1:f}, ${2:interval, ...,lower = min(interval), upper = max(interval),f.lower = f(lower, ...), f.upper = f(upper, ...),extendInt = c("no", "yes", "downX", "upX"), check.conv = FALSE,tol = .Machine$double.eps^0.25, maxiter = 1000, trace = 0)})
uniroot.displayText: uniroot(f, interval, ...,lower = min(interval), upper = max(interval),f.lower = f(lower, ...), f.upper = f(upper, ...),extendInt = c("no", "yes", "downX", "upX"), check.conv = FALSE,tol = .Machine$double.eps^0.25, maxiter = 1000, trace = 0)
uniroot.description: The function uniroot searches the interval from lower to upper for a root (i.e., zero) of the function f with respect to its first argument.

update.description: update.formula is used to update model formulae. This typically involves adding or dropping terms, but updates can be more general.

displayText: var.test(x, y, ratio = 1, alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"), conf.level = 0.95, ...)
var.test.description: Performs an F test to compare the variances of two samples from normal populations.
var.test.rightLabel: F Test to Compare Two Variances

vcov.description: Returns the variance-covariance matrix of the main parameters of a fitted model object.
vcov.rightLabel: Calculate Variance-Covariance Matrix for a Fitted Model Object

weighted.residuals.description: Computed weighted residuals from a linear model fit.

weights.1.description: weights is a generic function which extracts fitting weights from objects returned by modeling functions.

snippet: wilcox.test(${1:x}, ${2:y = NULL,alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),mu = 0, paired = FALSE, exact = NULL, correct = TRUE,conf.int = FALSE, conf.level = 0.95, ...)})
displayText: wilcox.test(x, y = NULL,alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),mu = 0, paired = FALSE, exact = NULL, correct = TRUE,conf.int = FALSE, conf.level = 0.95, ...)
wilcox.test.description: Performs one- and two-sample Wilcoxon tests on vectors of data; the latter is also known as ‘Mann-Whitney’ test.
wilcox.test.rightLabel: Wilcoxon Rank Sum and Signed Rank Tests

snippet: window(${1:x}, ${2:start = NULL, end = NULL,frequency = NULL, deltat = NULL, extend = FALSE, ...})
displayText: window(x, start = NULL, end = NULL,frequency = NULL, deltat = NULL, extend = FALSE, ...)
window.description: window is a generic function which extracts the subset of the object x observed between the times start and end. If a frequency is specified, the series is then re-sampled at the new frequency.

.getXlevels.description: .checkMFClasses checks if the variables used in a predict method agree in type with those used for fitting.
.getXlevels.rightLabel: Functions to Check the Type of Variables passed to Model Frames

add_datalist.description: The data() command with no arguments lists all the datasets available via data in attached packages, and to do so a per-package list is installed. Creating that list at install time can be slow for packages with huge datasets, and can be expedited by a supplying ‘data/datalist’ file.
add_datalist.rightLabel: Add a ‘datalist’ File to a Package

snippet: parse_Rd(${1:file}, ${2:srcfile = NULL, encoding = "unknown", verbose = FALSE, fragment = FALSE, warningCalls = TRUE,	 macros = file.path(R.home("share"), "Rd", "macros", "system.Rd"), permissive = FALSE})
displayText: parse_Rd(file, srcfile = NULL, encoding = "unknown", verbose = FALSE, fragment = FALSE, warningCalls = TRUE,	 macros = file.path(R.home("share"), "Rd", "macros", "system.Rd"), permissive = FALSE)
as.character.1.description: This function reads an R documentation (Rd) file and parses it, for processing by other functions.

assertCondition.description: When testing code, it is not sufficient to check that results are correct, but also that errors or warnings are signalled in appropriate situations. The functions described here provide a convenient facility for doing so. The three functions check that evaluating the supplied expression produces an error, a warning or one of a specified list of conditions, respectively. If the assertion fails, an error is signalled.

getBibstyle.description: This function defines and registers styles for rendering bibentry objects into ‘Rd’ format, for later conversion to text, HTML, etc.
getBibstyle.rightLabel: Select or define a bibliography style.

buildVignette.snippet: buildVignette(${1:file}, ${2:dir = ".", weave = TRUE, latex = TRUE, tangle = TRUE, quiet = TRUE, clean = TRUE, keep = character(),engine = NULL, buildPkg = NULL, encoding, ...)})
buildVignette.displayText: buildVignette(file, dir = ".", weave = TRUE, latex = TRUE, tangle = TRUE, quiet = TRUE, clean = TRUE, keep = character(),engine = NULL, buildPkg = NULL, encoding, ...)
buildVignette.description: Run Sweave (or other custom weave function) texi2dvi, and/or Stangle (or other custom tangle function) on one vignette.

snippet: buildVignettes(${1:package}, ${2:dir, lib.loc = NULL, quiet = TRUE, clean = TRUE, tangle = FALSE})
pkgVignettes(${1:package}, ${2:dir, subdirs = NULL, lib.loc = NULL,	 output = FALSE, source = FALSE, check = FALSE})
displayText: buildVignettes(package, dir, lib.loc = NULL, quiet = TRUE, clean = TRUE, tangle = FALSE)
pkgVignettes(package, dir, subdirs = NULL, lib.loc = NULL,	 output = FALSE, source = FALSE, check = FALSE)
pkgVignettes.description: Run Sweave (or other custom weave function) and texi2dvi on all vignettes of a package.

checkS3methods.description: Functions for performing various quality checks.
checkS3methods.rightLabel: QC Checks for R Code and/or Documentation

checkFF.snippet: checkFF(${1:package}, ${2:dir, file, lib.loc = NULL,registration = FALSE, check_DUP = FALSE,verbose = getOption("verbose"})
checkFF.displayText: checkFF(package, dir, file, lib.loc = NULL,registration = FALSE, check_DUP = FALSE,verbose = getOption("verbose")
checkFF.description: Performs checks on calls to compiled code from R code. Currently only checks whether the interface functions such as .C and .Fortran are called with a "NativeSymbolInfo" first argument or with argument PACKAGE specified, which is highly recommended to avoid name clashes in foreign function calls.

checkMD5sums.description: checkMD5sums checks the files against a file ‘MD5’.
checkMD5sums.rightLabel: Check and Create MD5 Checksum Files

checkPoFiles.description: These functions compare formats embedded in English messages with translated strings to check for consistency. checkPoFile checks one file, while checkPoFiles checks all files for a specified language.
checkPoFiles.rightLabel: Check translation files for inconsistent format strings.

checkRd.snippet: checkRd(${1:Rd}, ${2:defines = .Platform$OS.type, stages = "render",unknownOK = TRUE, listOK = TRUE, ..., def_enc = FALSE})
checkRd.displayText: checkRd(Rd, defines = .Platform$OS.type, stages = "render",unknownOK = TRUE, listOK = TRUE, ..., def_enc = FALSE)
checkRd.description: Check an help file or the output of the parse_Rd function.

resaveRdaFiles.description: This reports for each of the files produced by save the size, if it was saved in ASCII or XDR binary format, and if it was compressed (and if so in what format).
resaveRdaFiles.rightLabel: Report on Details of Saved Images or Re-saves them

checkTnF.description: Checks the specified R package or code file for occurrences of T or F, and gathers the expression containing these. This is useful as in R T and F are just variables which are set to the logicals TRUE and FALSE by default, but are not reserved words and hence can be overwritten by the user. Hence, one should always use TRUE and FALSE for the logicals.
checkTnF.rightLabel: Check R Packages or Code for T/F

checkVignettes.snippet: checkVignettes(${1:package}, ${2:dir, lib.loc = NULL, tangle = TRUE, weave = TRUE, latex = FALSE, workdir = c("tmp", "src", "cur"), keepfiles = FALSE)})
checkVignettes.displayText: checkVignettes(package, dir, lib.loc = NULL, tangle = TRUE, weave = TRUE, latex = FALSE, workdir = c("tmp", "src", "cur"), keepfiles = FALSE)
checkVignettes.description: Check all Sweave files of a package by running Sweave and/or Stangle on them. All R source code files found after the tangling step are sourceed to check whether all code can be executed without errors.

snippet: check_packages_in_dir(${1:dir},check_args = character(),check_args_db = list(),reverse = NULL,check_env = character(),xvfb = FALSE,Ncpus = getOption("Ncpus", 1L),clean = TRUE,...})
displayText: check_packages_in_dir(dir,check_args = character(),check_args_db = list(),reverse = NULL,check_env = character(),xvfb = FALSE,Ncpus = getOption("Ncpus", 1L),clean = TRUE,...)
check_packages_in_dir_changes.description: Check source packages in a given directory, optionally with their reverse dependencies.
check_packages_in_dir_changes.rightLabel: Check Source Packages and Their Reverse Dependencies

snippet: codoc(${1:package}, ${2:dir, lib.loc = NULL,use.values = NULL, verbose = getOption("verbose"})
displayText: codoc(package, dir, lib.loc = NULL,use.values = NULL, verbose = getOption("verbose")
codocData.description: Find inconsistencies between actual and documented ‘structure’ of R objects in a package. codoc compares names and optionally also corresponding positions and default values of the arguments of functions. codocClasses and codocData compare slot names of S4 classes and variable names of data sets, respectively.

snippet: compactPDF(${1:paths}, ${2:qpdf = Sys.which(Sys.getenv("R_QPDF", "qpdf")), gs_cmd = Sys.getenv("R_GSCMD", ""), gs_quality = Sys.getenv("GS_QUALITY", "none"), gs_extras = character())})
displayText: compactPDF(paths, qpdf = Sys.which(Sys.getenv("R_QPDF", "qpdf")), gs_cmd = Sys.getenv("R_GSCMD", ""), gs_quality = Sys.getenv("GS_QUALITY", "none"), gs_extras = character())
format.1.description: Re-save PDF files (especially vignettes) more compactly. Support function for R CMD build --compact-vignettes.

delimMatch.description: Match delimited substrings in a character vector, with proper nesting.

snippet: parseLatex(${1:text}, ${2:filename = deparse(substitute(text)), verbose = FALSE, verbatim = c("verbatim", "verbatim*","Sinput", "Soutput"})
displayText: parseLatex(text, filename = deparse(substitute(text)), verbose = FALSE, verbatim = c("verbatim", "verbatim*","Sinput", "Soutput")
latexToUtf8.description: The parseLatex function parses LaTeX source, producing a structured object; deparseLatex reverses the process. The latexToUtf8 function takes a LaTeX object, and processes a number of different macros to convert them into the corresponding UTF-8 characters.
latexToUtf8.rightLabel: These experimental functions work with a subset of LaTeX code.

dependsOnPkgs.snippet: dependsOnPkgs(${1:pkgs},dependencies = c("Depends", "Imports", "LinkingTo"),recursive = TRUE, lib.loc = NULL,installed =utils::installed.packages(lib.loc, fields = "Enhances")})
dependsOnPkgs.displayText: dependsOnPkgs(pkgs,dependencies = c("Depends", "Imports", "LinkingTo"),recursive = TRUE, lib.loc = NULL,installed =utils::installed.packages(lib.loc, fields = "Enhances")
dependsOnPkgs.description: Find ‘reverse’ dependencies of packages, that is those packages which depend on this one, and (optionally) so on recursively.

encoded_text_to_latex.description: Translate non-ASCII characters in text to LaTeX escape sequences.
encoded_text_to_latex.rightLabel: Translate non-ASCII Text to LaTeX Escapes

snippet: list_files_with_type(${1:dir}, ${2:type, all.files = FALSE, full.names = TRUE, OS_subdirs = .OStype(})
displayText: list_files_with_exts(dir, exts, all.files = FALSE, full.names = TRUE)
list_files_with_type(dir, type, all.files = FALSE, full.names = TRUE, OS_subdirs = .OStype()
list_files_with_type.description: Utilities for listing files, and manipulating file paths.

findHTMLlinks.description: Compute relative file paths for URLs to other package's installed HTML documentation.
findHTMLlinks.rightLabel: Collect HTML Links from Package Documentation

find_gs_cmd.description: Find a GhostScript executable in a cross-platform way.

snippet: getDepList(${1:depMtrx}, ${2:instPkgs, recursive = TRUE, local = TRUE, reduce = TRUE, lib.loc = NULL})
pkgDepends(${1:pkg}, ${2:recursive = TRUE, local = TRUE, reduce = TRUE, lib.loc = NULL})
displayText: getDepList(depMtrx, instPkgs, recursive = TRUE, local = TRUE, reduce = TRUE, lib.loc = NULL)
pkgDepends(pkg, recursive = TRUE, local = TRUE, reduce = TRUE, lib.loc = NULL)
pkgDepends.description: Given a dependency matrix, will create a DependsList object for that package which will include the dependencies for that matrix, which ones are installed, which unresolved dependencies were found online, which unresolved dependencies were not found online, and any R dependencies.

getVignetteInfo.displayText: getVignetteInfo(package = NULL, lib.loc = NULL, all = TRUE)
getVignetteInfo.description: This function gets information on installed vignettes.

startDynamicHelp.description: This function starts the internal help server, so that HTML help pages are rendered when requested.
startDynamicHelp.rightLabel: Start the Dynamic HTML Help System

HTMLheader.snippet: HTMLheader(${1:title = "R"}, ${2:logo = TRUE, up = NULL, top = file.path(Rhome, "doc/html/index.html"), Rhome = "", css = file.path(Rhome, "doc/html/R.css"), headerTitle = paste("R:", title), outputEncoding = "UTF-8")})
HTMLheader.displayText: HTMLheader(title = "R", logo = TRUE, up = NULL, top = file.path(Rhome, "doc/html/index.html"), Rhome = "", css = file.path(Rhome, "doc/html/R.css"), headerTitle = paste("R:", title), outputEncoding = "UTF-8")
HTMLheader.description: This function generates the standard HTML header used on R help pages.
HTMLheader.rightLabel: Generate a standard HTML header for R help

installFoundDepends.description: This function will take the Found element of a pkgDependsList object and attempt to install all of the listed packages from the specified repositories.
installFoundDepends.rightLabel: A function to install unresolved dependencies

loadPkgRdMacros.description: Loads macros from an ‘.Rd’ file, or from several ‘.Rd’ files contained in a package.
loadPkgRdMacros.rightLabel: Load user-defined Rd help system macros.

makevars_site.description: Determine the location of the user and site specific ‘Makevars’ files for customizing package compilation.

make_translations_pkg.description: A utility for R Core members to prepare a package of updated translations.
make_translations_pkg.rightLabel: Package the Current Translations in the R sources

md5sum.description: Compute the 32-byte MD5 hashes of one or more files.

package.dependencies.description: Parses and checks the dependencies of a package against the currently installed version of R (and other packages).

package_dependencies.snippet: package_dependencies(${1:packages = NULL}, ${2:db,which = c("Depends", "Imports", "LinkingTo"),	recursive = FALSE, reverse = FALSE, verbose = getOption("verbose")})
package_dependencies.displayText: package_dependencies(packages = NULL, db,which = c("Depends", "Imports", "LinkingTo"),	recursive = FALSE, reverse = FALSE, verbose = getOption("verbose")
package_dependencies.description: Find (recursively) dependencies or reverse dependencies of packages.
package_dependencies.rightLabel: Computations on the Dependency Hierarchy of Packages

undoc.description: Finds the objects in a package which are undocumented, in the sense that they are visible to the user (or data objects or S4 classes provided by the package), but no documentation entry exists.

pskill.description: pskill sends a signal to a process, usually to terminate it.

psnice.description: Get or set the ‘niceness’ of the current process, or one or more other processes.
psnice.rightLabel: Get or Set the Priority (Niceness) of a Process

Rcmd.description: Invoke R CMD tools from within R.

snippet: Rd2HTML(${1:Rd}, ${2:out = "", package = "", defines = .Platform$OS.type,Links = NULL, Links2 = NULL,stages = "render", outputEncoding = "UTF-8",dynamic = FALSE, no_links = FALSE, fragment = FALSE,stylesheet = "R.css", ...})
Rd2txt(${1:Rd}, ${2:out = "", package = "", defines = .Platform$OS.type, stages = "render", outputEncoding = "", fragment = FALSE, options, ...})
Rd2latex(${1:Rd}, ${2:out = "", defines = .Platform$OS.type, stages = "render", outputEncoding = "ASCII", fragment = FALSE, ..., writeEncoding = TRUE})
Rd2ex(${1:Rd}, ${2:out = "", defines = .Platform$OS.type,stages = "render", outputEncoding = "UTF-8",commentDontrun = TRUE, commentDonttest = FALSE, ...})
displayText: Rd2HTML(Rd, out = "", package = "", defines = .Platform$OS.type,Links = NULL, Links2 = NULL,stages = "render", outputEncoding = "UTF-8",dynamic = FALSE, no_links = FALSE, fragment = FALSE,stylesheet = "R.css", ...)
Rd2txt(Rd, out = "", package = "", defines = .Platform$OS.type, stages = "render", outputEncoding = "", fragment = FALSE, options, ...)
Rd2latex(Rd, out = "", defines = .Platform$OS.type, stages = "render", outputEncoding = "ASCII", fragment = FALSE, ..., writeEncoding = TRUE)
Rd2ex(Rd, out = "", defines = .Platform$OS.type,stages = "render", outputEncoding = "UTF-8",commentDontrun = TRUE, commentDonttest = FALSE, ...)
Rd2ex.description: These functions take the output of the parse_Rd function and produce a help page from it. As they are mainly intended for internal use, their interfaces are subject to change.

Rd2txt_options.description: This function sets various options for displaying text help.
Rd2txt_options.rightLabel: Set formatting options for text help

Rdiff.snippet: Rdiff(${1:from}, ${2:to, useDiff = FALSE, forEx = FALSE,nullPointers = TRUE, Log = FALSE})
Rdiff.displayText: Rdiff(from, to, useDiff = FALSE, forEx = FALSE,nullPointers = TRUE, Log = FALSE)
Rdiff.description: Given two R output files, compute differences ignoring headers, footers and some other differences.

Rdindex.snippet: Rdindex(${1:RdFiles}, ${2:outFile = "", type = NULL,width = 0.9 * getOption("width"), indent = NULL)})
Rdindex.displayText: Rdindex(RdFiles, outFile = "", type = NULL,width = 0.9 * getOption("width"), indent = NULL)
Rdindex.description: Print a 2-column index table with names and titles from given R documentation files to a given output file or connection. The titles are nicely formatted between two column positions (typically 25 and 72, respectively).

RdTextFilter.snippet: RdTextFilter(${1:ifile}, ${2:encoding = "unknown", keepSpacing = TRUE, drop = character(), keep = character(), macros = file.path(R.home("share"), "Rd", "macros", "system.Rd")})
RdTextFilter.displayText: RdTextFilter(ifile, encoding = "unknown", keepSpacing = TRUE, drop = character(), keep = character(), macros = file.path(R.home("share"), "Rd", "macros", "system.Rd")
RdTextFilter.description: This function blanks out all non-text in an Rd file, for spell checking or other uses.
RdTextFilter.rightLabel: Select text in an Rd file.

Rd_db.description: Utilities for computing on the information in Rd objects.

read.00Index.description: Read item/description information from ‘00Index’-like files. Such files are description lists rendered in tabular form, and currently used for the ‘INDEX’ and ‘demo/00Index’ files of add-on packages.

showNonASCIIfile.description: This function prints elements of a character vector which contain non-ASCII bytes, printing such bytes as a escape like <fc>.

SweaveTeXFilter.description: This function blanks out code chunks and Noweb markup in an Sweave input file, for spell checking or other uses.
SweaveTeXFilter.rightLabel: Strip R code out of Sweave file

snippet: testInstalledPackage(${1:pkg}, ${2:lib.loc = NULL, outDir = ".", types = c("examples", "tests", "vignettes"), srcdir = NULL, Ropts = "", ...)})
testInstalledPackages(${1:outDir = "."}, ${2:errorsAreFatal = TRUE,scope = c("both", "base", "recommended"),types = c("examples", "tests", "vignettes"),srcdir = NULL, Ropts = "", ...})
displayText: testInstalledPackage(pkg, lib.loc = NULL, outDir = ".", types = c("examples", "tests", "vignettes"), srcdir = NULL, Ropts = "", ...)
testInstalledPackages(outDir = ".", errorsAreFatal = TRUE,scope = c("both", "base", "recommended"),types = c("examples", "tests", "vignettes"),srcdir = NULL, Ropts = "", ...)
testInstalledBasic.description: These functions allow an installed package to be tested, or all base and recommended packages.

snippet: texi2dvi(${1:file}, ${2:pdf = FALSE, clean = FALSE, quiet = TRUE, texi2dvi = getOption("texi2dvi"), texinputs = NULL, index = TRUE)})
texi2pdf(${1:file}, ${2:clean = FALSE, quiet = TRUE, texi2dvi = getOption("texi2dvi"), texinputs = NULL, index = TRUE)})
displayText: texi2dvi(file, pdf = FALSE, clean = FALSE, quiet = TRUE, texi2dvi = getOption("texi2dvi"), texinputs = NULL, index = TRUE)
texi2pdf(file, clean = FALSE, quiet = TRUE, texi2dvi = getOption("texi2dvi"), texinputs = NULL, index = TRUE)
texi2pdf.description: Run latex/pdflatex, makeindex and bibtex until all cross-references are resolved to create a dvi or a PDF file.

toHTML.description: This generic function generates a complete HTML page from an object.

toRd.description: Methods for this function render their associated classes as a fragment of Rd code, which can then be rendered into text, HTML, or LaTeX.
toRd.rightLabel: Generic function to convert object to a fragment of Rd code.

toTitleCase.description: Convert a character vector to title case, especially package titles.

update_pkg_po.snippet: update_pkg_po(${1:pkgdir}, ${2:pkg = NULL, version = NULL, copyright, bugs})
update_pkg_po.displayText: update_pkg_po(pkgdir, pkg = NULL, version = NULL, copyright, bugs)
update_pkg_po.description: Prepare the ‘po’ directory of a package and compile and install the translations.

vignetteDepends.snippet: vignetteDepends(${1:vignette}, ${2:recursive = TRUE, reduce = TRUE,local = TRUE, lib.loc = NULL})
vignetteDepends.displayText: vignetteDepends(vignette, recursive = TRUE, reduce = TRUE,local = TRUE, lib.loc = NULL)
vignetteDepends.description: Given a vignette name, will create a DependsList object that reports information about the packages the vignette depends on.
vignetteDepends.rightLabel: Retrieve Dependency Information for a Vignette

vignetteEngine.snippet: vignetteEngine(${1:name}, ${2:weave, tangle, pattern = NULL,	 package = NULL, aspell = list(})
vignetteEngine.displayText: vignetteEngine(name, weave, tangle, pattern = NULL,	 package = NULL, aspell = list()
vignetteEngine.description: Vignettes are normally processed by Sweave, but package writers may choose to use a different engine (e.g., one provided by the knitr, noweb or R.rsp packages). This function is used by those packages to register their engines, and internally by R to retrieve them.
vignetteEngine.rightLabel: Set or Get a Vignette Processing Engine

write_PACKAGES.snippet: write_PACKAGES(${1:dir = "."}, ${2:fields = NULL, type = c("source", "mac.binary", "win.binary"), verbose = FALSE, unpacked = FALSE, subdirs = FALSE, latestOnly = TRUE, addFiles = FALSE)})
write_PACKAGES.displayText: write_PACKAGES(dir = ".", fields = NULL, type = c("source", "mac.binary", "win.binary"), verbose = FALSE, unpacked = FALSE, subdirs = FALSE, latestOnly = TRUE, addFiles = FALSE)
write_PACKAGES.description: Generate ‘PACKAGES’ and ‘PACKAGES.gz’ files for a repository of source or Mac/Windows binary packages.

xgettext2pot.description: For each file in the ‘R’ directory (including system-specific subdirectories) of a package, extract the unique arguments passed to stop, warning, message, gettext and gettextf, or to ngettext.
xgettext2pot.rightLabel: Extract Translatable Messages from R Files in a Package

adist.snippet: adist(${1:x}, ${2:y = NULL, costs = NULL, counts = FALSE, fixed = TRUE,partial = !fixed, ignore.case = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE})
adist.displayText: adist(x, y = NULL, costs = NULL, counts = FALSE, fixed = TRUE,partial = !fixed, ignore.case = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE)
adist.description: Compute the approximate string distance between character vectors. The distance is a generalized Levenshtein (edit) distance, giving the minimal possibly weighted number of insertions, deletions and substitutions needed to transform one string into another.

alarm.description: Gives an audible or visual signal to the user.

displayText: apropos(what, where = FALSE, ignore.case = TRUE, mode = "any")
find(what, mode = "any", numeric = FALSE, simple.words = TRUE)
find.description: apropos() returns a character vector giving the names of all objects in the search list matching what.

aregexec.snippet: aregexec(${1:pattern}, ${2:text, max.distance = 0.1, costs = NULL, ignore.case = FALSE, fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE})
aregexec.displayText: aregexec(pattern, text, max.distance = 0.1, costs = NULL, ignore.case = FALSE, fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE)
aregexec.description: Determine positions of approximate string matches.

argsAnywhere.description: These functions locate all objects with name matching their argument, whether visible on the search path, registered as an S3 method or in a namespace but not exported. getAnywhere() returns the objects and argsAnywhere() returns the arguments of any objects that are functions.
argsAnywhere.rightLabel: Retrieve an R Object, Including from a Namespace

snippet: person(${1:given = NULL}, ${2:family = NULL, middle = NULL, email = NULL, role = NULL, comment = NULL, first = NULL, last = NULL})

format.2.description: A class and utility methods for holding information about persons like name and email address.

unlist.1.description: relist() is an S3 generic function with a few methods in order to allow easy inversion of unlist(obj) when that is used with an object obj of (S3) class "relistable".

as.roman.description: Simple manipulation of (a small set of) integer numbers as roman numerals.

aspell.snippet: aspell(${1:files}, ${2:filter, control = list(), encoding = "unknown", program = NULL, dictionaries = character()})

combn.displayText: combn(x, m, FUN = NULL, simplify = TRUE, ...)
combn.description: Generate all combinations of the elements of x taken m at a time. If x is a positive integer, returns all combinations of the elements of seq(x) taken m at a time. If argument FUN is not NULL, applies a function given by the argument to each point. If simplify is FALSE, returns a list; otherwise returns an array, typically a matrix. ... are passed unchanged to the FUN function, if specified.
combn.rightLabel: Generate All Combinations of n Elements, Taken m at a Time

format.description: Compactly display the internal structure of an R object, a diagnostic function and an alternative to summary (and to some extent, dput). Ideally, only one line for each ‘basic’ structure is displayed. It is especially well suited to compactly display the (abbreviated) contents of (possibly nested) lists. The idea is to give reasonable output for any R object. It calls args for (non-primitive) function objects.
format.rightLabel: Compactly Display the Structure of an Arbitrary R Object

addmargins.1.displayText: addmargins(A, margin = seq_along(dim(A)), FUN = sum, quiet = FALSE)
addmargins.1.description: For a given table one can specify which of the classifying factors to expand by one or more levels to hold margins to be calculated. One may for example form sums and means over the first dimension and medians over the second. The resulting table will then have two extra levels for the first dimension and one extra level for the second. The default is to sum over all margins in the table. Other possibilities may give results that depend on the order in which the margins are computed. This is flagged in the printed output from the function.

aggregate.1.description: Splits the data into subsets, computes summary statistics for each, and returns the result in a convenient form.

BIC.1.description: Generic function calculating Akaike's ‘An Information Criterion’ for one or several fitted model objects for which a log-likelihood value can be obtained, according to the formula -2*log-likelihood + k*npar, where npar represents the number of parameters in the fitted model, and k = 2 for the usual AIC, or k = log(n) (n being the number of observations) for the so-called BIC or SBC (Schwarz's Bayesian criterion).

I.e., fn(t) =   c[i] (constant) for t in (   x[i], x[i+1]) and at the abscissa values, if (by default) right = FALSE, fn(x[i]) = y[i] and for right = TRUE, fn(x[i]) = y[i-1], for i=1, …, n.

heatmap.1.description: A heat map is a false color image (basically image(t(x))) with a dendrogram added to the left side and to the top. Typically, reordering of the rows and columns according to some set of values (row or column means) within the restrictions imposed by the dendrogram is carried out.

identify.1.description: identify.hclust reads the position of the graphics pointer when the (first) mouse button is pressed. It then cuts the tree at the vertical position of the pointer and highlights the cluster containing the horizontal position of the pointer. Optionally a function is applied to the index of data points contained in the cluster.

lm.influence.1.description: This function provides the basic quantities which are used in forming a wide variety of diagnostics for checking the quality of regression fits.

integrate.1.description: Adaptive quadrature of functions of one variable over a finite or infinite interval.

interaction.plot.1.description: Plots the mean (or other summary) of the response for two-way combinations of factors, thereby illustrating possible interactions.

IQR.1.description: computes interquartile range of the x values.

is.empty.model.1.description: R's formula notation allows models with no intercept and no predictors. These require special handling internally. is.empty.model() checks whether an object describes an empty model.

isoreg.1.description: Compute the isotonic (monotonely increasing nonparametric) least squares regression which is piecewise constant.

makeARIMA.1.description: Use Kalman Filtering to find the (Gaussian) log-likelihood, or for forecasting or smoothing.

kernapply.1.description: kernapply computes the convolution between an input sequence and a specific kernel.

kruskal.test.1.description: Performs a Kruskal-Wallis rank sum test.

ks.test.1.description: Perform a one- or two-sample Kolmogorov-Smirnov test.

labels.4.description: Theses functions return the order (index) or the "label" attribute for the leaves in a dendrogram. These indices can then be used to access the appropriate components of any additional data.

terms.2.description: The function terms is a generic function which can be used to extract terms objects from various kinds of R data objects.

lag.1.description: Compute a lagged version of a time series, shifting the time base back by a given number of observations.

line.1.description: Fit a line robustly as recommended in Exploratory Data Analysis.

.lm.fit.1.description: These are the basic computing engines called by lm used to fit linear models. These should usually not be used directly unless by experienced users. .lm.fit() is bare bone wrapper to the innermost QR-based C code, on which glm.fit and lsfit are based as well, for even more experienced users.

print.22.description: Extract or print loadings in factor analysis (or principal components analysis).

loess.1.description: Fit a polynomial surface determined by one or more numerical predictors, using local fitting.

logLik.1.description: This function is generic; method functions can be written to handle specific classes of objects. Classes which have methods for this function include: "glm", "lm", "nls" and "Arima". Packages contain methods for other classes, such as "fitdistr", "negbin" and "polr" in package MASS, "multinom" in package nnet and "gls", "gnls" "lme" and others in package nlme.

lowess.1.description: This function performs the computations for the LOWESS smoother which uses locally-weighted polynomial regression (see the references).

ls.diag.1.description: Computes basic statistics, including standard errors, t- and p-values for the regression coefficients.

ls.print.1.description: Computes basic statistics, including standard errors, t- and p-values for the regression coefficients and prints them if print.it is TRUE.

lsfit.1.description: The least squares estimate of b in the model

mad.1.displayText: mad(x, center = median(x), constant = 1.4826, na.rm = FALSE,low = FALSE, high = FALSE)
mad.1.description: Compute the median absolute deviation, i.e., the (lo-/hi-) median of the absolute deviations from the median, and (by default) adjust by a factor for asymptotically normal consistency.

mahalanobis.1.description: Returns the squared Mahalanobis distance of all rows in x and the vector mu = center with respect to Sigma = cov. This is (for vector x) defined as

make.link.1.description: This function is used with the family functions in glm(). Given the name of a link, it returns a link function, an inverse link function, the derivative dmu/deta and a function for domain checking.

makepredictcall.1.description: A utility to help model.frame.default create the right matrices when predicting from models with terms like (univariate) poly or ns.

snippet: poly(${1:x}, ${2:..., degree = 1, coefs = NULL, raw = FALSE, simple = FALSE})
displayText: poly(x, ..., degree = 1, coefs = NULL, raw = FALSE, simple = FALSE)
polym(..., degree = 1, coefs = NULL, raw = FALSE)
predict.14.description: Returns or evaluates orthogonal polynomials of degree 1 to degree over the specified set of points x: these are all orthogonal to the constant polynomial of degree 0. Alternatively, evaluate raw polynomials.

manova.1.description: A class for the multivariate analysis of variance.

mantelhaen.test.1.snippet: mantelhaen.test(${1:x}, ${2:y = NULL, z = NULL,alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),correct = TRUE, exact = FALSE, conf.level = 0.95)})

mantelhaen.test.1.description: Performs a Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel chi-squared test of the null that two nominal variables are conditionally independent in each stratum, assuming that there is no three-way interaction.

snippet: mauchly.test(${1:object}, ${2:Sigma = diag(nrow = p), T = Thin.row(proj(M) - proj(X)), M = diag(nrow = p), X = ~0, idata = data.frame(index = seq_len(p)), ...)})

mauchly.test.1.description: Tests whether a Wishart-distributed covariance matrix (or transformation thereof) is proportional to a given matrix.

mcnemar.test.1.description: Performs McNemar's chi-squared test for symmetry of rows and columns in a two-dimensional contingency table.

medpolish.1.displayText: medpolish(x, eps = 0.01, maxiter = 10, trace.iter = TRUE,na.rm = FALSE)
medpolish.1.description: Fits an additive model using Tukey's median polish procedure.

model.weights.1.description: Returns the response, offset, subset, weights or other special components of a model frame passed as optional arguments to model.frame.

displayText: model.matrix(object, data = environment(object), contrasts.arg = NULL, xlev = NULL, ...)
model.matrix.1.description: model.matrix creates a design (or model) matrix, e.g., by expanding factors to a set of dummary variables (depending on the contrasts) and expanding interactions similarly.

model.tables.1.description: Computes summary tables for model fits, especially complex aov fits.

monthplot.1.description: These functions plot seasonal (or other) subseries of a time series. For each season (or other category), a time series is plotted.

mood.test.1.description: Performs Mood's two-sample test for a difference in scale parameters.

na.action.1.description: Extract information on the NA action used to create an object.

na.contiguous.1.description: Find the longest consecutive stretch of non-missing values in a time series object. (In the event of a tie, the first such stretch.)

na.pass.1.description: These generic functions are useful for dealing with NAs in e.g., data frames. na.fail returns the object if it does not contain any missing values, and signals an error otherwise. na.omit returns the object with incomplete cases removed. na.pass returns the object unchanged.

napredict.1.description: Use missing value information to adjust residuals and predictions.

naprint.1.description: Use missing value information to report the effects of an na.action.

nextn.1.description: nextn returns the smallest integer, greater than or equal to n, which can be obtained as a product of powers of the values contained in factors. nextn is intended to be used to find a suitable length to zero-pad the argument of fft to so that the transform is computed quickly. The default value for factors ensures this.

nlm.1.snippet: nlm(${1:f}, ${2:p, ..., hessian = FALSE, typsize = rep(1, length(p)),fscale = 1, print.level = 0, ndigit = 12, gradtol = 1e-6,stepmax = max(1000 * sqrt(sum((p/typsize)^2)), 1000),steptol = 1e-6, iterlim = 100, check.analyticals = TRUE})
nlm.1.displayText: nlm(f, p, ..., hessian = FALSE, typsize = rep(1, length(p)),fscale = 1, print.level = 0, ndigit = 12, gradtol = 1e-6,stepmax = max(1000 * sqrt(sum((p/typsize)^2)), 1000),steptol = 1e-6, iterlim = 100, check.analyticals = TRUE)
nlm.1.description: This function carries out a minimization of the function f using a Newton-type algorithm. See the references for details.

nlminb.1.snippet: nlminb(${1:start}, ${2:objective, gradient = NULL, hessian = NULL, ..., scale = 1, control = list(), lower = -Inf, upper = Inf)})
nlminb.1.displayText: nlminb(start, objective, gradient = NULL, hessian = NULL, ..., scale = 1, control = list(), lower = -Inf, upper = Inf)
nlminb.1.description: Unconstrained and box-constrained optimization using PORT routines.

nls.1.snippet: nls(${1:formula}, ${2:data, start, control, algorithm,trace, subset, weights, na.action, model,lower, upper, ...})
nls.1.displayText: nls(formula, data, start, control, algorithm,trace, subset, weights, na.action, model,lower, upper, ...)
nls.1.description: Determine the nonlinear (weighted) least-squares estimates of the parameters of a nonlinear model.

nls.control.1.displayText: nls.control(maxiter = 50, tol = 1e-05, minFactor = 1/1024,printEval = FALSE, warnOnly = FALSE)
nls.control.1.description: Allow the user to set some characteristics of the nls nonlinear least squares algorithm.

NLSstAsymptotic.1.description: Fits the asymptotic regression model, in the form b0 +    b1*(1-exp(-exp(lrc) * x) to the xy data. This can be used as a building block in determining starting estimates for more complicated models.

NLSstClosestX.1.description: Use inverse linear interpolation to approximate the x value at which the function represented by xy is equal to yval.

NLSstLfAsymptote.1.description: Provide an initial guess at the horizontal asymptote on the left side (i.e., small values of x) of the graph of y versus x from the xy object. Primarily used within initial functions for self-starting nonlinear regression models.

NLSstRtAsymptote.1.description: Provide an initial guess at the horizontal asymptote on the right side (i.e., large values of x) of the graph of y versus x from the xy object. Primarily used within initial functions for self-starting nonlinear regression models.

nobs.1.description: Extract the number of ‘observations’ from a model fit. This is principally intended to be used in computing BIC (see AIC).

numericDeriv.1.description: numericDeriv numerically evaluates the gradient of an expression.

offset.1.description: An offset is a term to be added to a linear predictor, such as in a generalised linear model, with known coefficient 1 rather than an estimated coefficient.

oneway.test.1.displayText: oneway.test(formula, data, subset, na.action, var.equal = FALSE)
oneway.test.1.description: Test whether two or more samples from normal distributions have the same means. The variances are not necessarily assumed to be equal.

plot.14.displayText: plot(x, which = c(1:3, 5),caption = list("Residuals vs Fitted", "Normal Q-Q", "Scale-Location", "Cook's distance", "Residuals vs Leverage", expression("Cook's dist vs Leverage" * h[ii] / (1 - h[ii]))), panel = if(add.smooth) panel.smooth else points, sub.caption = NULL, main = "", ask = prod(par("mfcol")) < length(which) && dev.interactive(), ..., id.n = 3, labels.id = names(residuals(x)), cex.id = 0.75, qqline = TRUE, cook.levels = c(0.5, 1.0), add.smooth = getOption("add.smooth"), label.pos = c(4,2), cex.caption = 1, cex.oma.main = 1.25)
plot.14.description: Six plots (selectable by which) are currently available: a plot of residuals against fitted values, a Scale-Location plot of sqrt(| residuals |) against fitted values, a Normal Q-Q plot, a plot of Cook's distances versus row labels, a plot of residuals against leverages, and a plot of Cook's distances against leverage/(1-leverage). By default, the first three and 5 are provided.

poisson.test.1.description: Performs an exact test of a simple null hypothesis about the rate parameter in Poisson distribution, or for the ratio between two rate parameters.

power.1.description: Creates a link object based on the link function η = μ ^ λ.

PP.test.1.description: Computes the Phillips-Perron test for the null hypothesis that x has a unit root against a stationary alternative.

ppoints.1.description: Generates the sequence of probability points (1:m - a)/(m + (1-a)-a) where m is either n, if length(n)==1, or length(n).

predict.19.description: Computes predictions and prediction intervals for models fitted by the Holt-Winters method.

predict.21.description: Predictions from a loess fit, optionally with standard errors.

predict.22.snippet: predict(${1:object}, ${2:newdata , se.fit = FALSE, scale = NULL, df = Inf,interval = c("none", "confidence", "prediction"),level = 0.95, ...)})
predict.22.displayText: predict(object, newdata , se.fit = FALSE, scale = NULL, df = Inf,interval = c("none", "confidence", "prediction"),level = 0.95, ...)
predict.22.description: predict.nls produces predicted values, obtained by evaluating the regression function in the frame newdata. If the logical se.fit is TRUE, standard errors of the predictions are calculated. If the numeric argument scale is set (with optional df), it is used as the residual standard deviation in the computation of the standard errors, otherwise this is extracted from the model fit. Setting intervals specifies computation of confidence or prediction (tolerance) intervals at the specified level.

predict.23.description: Predict a smoothing spline fit at new points, return the derivative if desired. The predicted fit is linear beyond the original data.

preplot.1.description: Compute an object to be used for plots relating to the given model object.

print.23.description: Printing objects of class "htest" or "power.htest", respectively, by simple print methods.

print(x, digits = max(3, getOption("digits") - 3),symbolic.cor = x$symbolic.cor,signif.stars = getOption("show.signif.stars"), ...)

.preformat.ts.1.description: Notably for calendar related time series objects,  format and print methods showing years, months and or quarters respectively.

xtabs.1.description: Create a contingency table (optionally a sparse matrix) from cross-classifying factors, usually contained in a data frame, using a formula interface.

printCoefmat.1.description: Utility function to be used in higher-level print methods, such as those for summary.lm, summary.glm and anova. The goal is to provide a flexible interface with smart defaults such that often, only x needs to be specified.

profile.2.description: Investigates behavior of objective function near the solution represented by fitted.

profile.3.description: Investigates the profile log-likelihood function for a fitted model of class "nls".

proj.1.description: proj returns a matrix or list of matrices giving the projections of the data onto the terms of a linear model. It is most frequently used for aov models.

promax.1.description: These functions ‘rotate’ loading matrices in factor analysis.

prop.test.1.snippet: prop.test(${1:x}, ${2:n, p = NULL,alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),conf.level = 0.95, correct = TRUE)})
prop.test.1.displayText: prop.test(x, n, p = NULL,alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),conf.level = 0.95, correct = TRUE)
prop.test.1.description: prop.test can be used for testing the null that the proportions (probabilities of success) in several groups are the same, or that they equal certain given values.

prop.trend.test.1.description: Performs chi-squared test for trend in proportions, i.e., a test asymptotically optimal for local alternatives where the log odds vary in proportion with score. By default, score is chosen as the group numbers.

snippet: ptukey(${1:q}, ${2:nmeans, df, nranges = 1, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE})
qtukey(${1:p}, ${2:nmeans, df, nranges = 1, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE})

qtukey(p, nmeans, df, nranges = 1, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE)
qtukey.1.description: Functions of the distribution of the studentized range, R/s, where R is the range of a standard normal sample and df*s^2 is independently distributed as chi-squared with df degrees of freedom, see pchisq.
